dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Tuesday, April 28th 1992 WIDE-SHOT: A vast, snow-blanketed wilderness that sits beneath the icy summits of the highest mountain range in North America. This is BIG Alaska. A beat up 4x4 pick-up enters very small into the upper left corner of frame on an unkept, snow-packed road, and comes to a stop. A figure exits the passenger side and moves around the front of the truck. We can just make out the rifle sticking out of his backpack. We HEAR a very distant "Thank You" as the figure walks away from the road and away from the truck, seemingly into nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! The figure with backpack and rifle, henceforth BACKPACK, stopping in his tracks, turns around in the direction of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here. BACKPACK walks back to the truck.    As he approaches the driver's door, we CUT IN TO: TIGHT SHOT over the back-packed shoulder onto the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to items we see sitting on dashboard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left your watch, your comb, your change... We STAY on the DRIVER as BACKPACK speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your money.    And I already have a watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't take it, I'm gonna throw it away. I don't want to know what time it is, what day it is, or where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see anybody. None of that matters. The driver reaches behind the seat of the truck, pulls out an old pair of rubber work boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him the boots)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take em. There is a pause as Backpack considers accepting the boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you make it out alive, give me a call, and I'll tell you how to get the boots back to me. We can feel over Backpack's shoulder that he has taken the boots and is putting them on but we STAY on the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, do me a favor, will ya?     Take a picture of me. Backpack hands him an Instamatic camera and starts walking backwards. We PULL BACK with him. And he maintains his back to us. When he stops, we CONTINUE until he is FULL-FRAME, head-to-toe from behind, posing.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: May 1990 The crowd of family and friends, and of course, students. Assembled on fold-out chairs. The broad lawn. INTERCUT: CHRIS MCCANDLESS. We don't see his face, just feet pounding the pavement at an increasing pace. One by one the names of graduates announced. Their bright young faces, capped heads, and gowns, glide up to the podium to accept their diplomas. INTERCUT: Chris, on his run, sweatshirt hood over head. Amongst assembled crowd and family we find: THE MCCANDLESS': BILLIE, mid to late forties with dark striking eyes; WALT, a taciturn man, early fifties; and CARINE, eighteen, pretty with her mother's eyes and waist length brown hair, a gold crucifix dangles from her neck. They look around, looking for Chris, he's nowhere in sight. INTERCUT: Chris, in a shower (PHOTO-SONICS) He TURNS INTO CAMERA, the water streaming down his face. From the announcement podium comes the name of their son and brother, CHRISTOPHER JOHNSON MCCANDLESS. The McCandless family increasingly panicked over Chris' absence, when almost magically, he appears in full cap and gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disregarding the steps that lead up to the podium platform, the small-framed but athletic CHRIS MCCANDLESS leaps jubilantly onto the stage in a single bound, frightening Billie, a little wince from Walt, and Carine "That's our Chris." And just as quickly as Chris has been handed his diploma, he civilly descends the platform steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLO-MO: A ballet of graduation caps float upward into a frame of blue sky. We HEAR Chris' voice OVER this image as we intermittently cut away from the caps against the sky to focus on his parents. (HIGH ANGLE: floating caps in FOREGROUND, Walt and Billie delight upon the caps.) An outer glee in sharp contrast to voice over: CHRIS (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see them standing at the formal gates of their colleges, I see my father strolling out under the ochre sandstone arch, the red tiles glinting like bent plates of blood behind his head, I see my mother with a few light books at her hip standing at the pillar made of tiny bricks with the wrought-iron gate still open behind her, its sword-tips black in the May air, they are about to graduate, they are about to get married, they are kids, they are dumb, all they know is they are innocent, they would never hurt anybody. I want to go up to them and say Stop, don't do it--she's the wrong woman, he's the wrong man, you are going to do things you cannot imagine you would ever do, you are going to do bad things to children, you are going to suffer in ways you never heard of, you are going to want to die. I want to go up to them there in the late May sunlight and say it, her hungry pretty blank face turning to me, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her pitiful beautiful untouched body, his arrogant handsome blind face turning to me, his pitiful beautiful untouched body, but I don't do it. I want to live. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a warm ambient light, we SEE a black and white poster on a barren wall: Poncho-clad Clint Eastwood from "The Good, The Bad, And The Ugly." We TILT DOWN a stack of books sitting on the floor - Tolstoy, Stegner, Thoreau, Jack London, and Pasternak. Beside them, a camper's backpack. Chris sits in introspection at his desk by candlelight. The room is spare, supporting his monkish lifestyle. But on the desk before him, he counts out $500.68 from a bank envelope. He pockets those bills and change, then removes a check for $24,000 made out to OXFAM America from the same bank envelope. He scribbles a note: These are all my savings. Feed someone with it. Signed, Chris McCandless. He then slides the note and the check into a pre-addressed Oxford Famine Relief Fund (in Boston) envelope. He pulls his wallet from his back pocket. Pulls all the cards and pictures from its sleeves. Considering each, he flicks them into a trash bin, one by one. Finally coming to his social security card, he holds it to the candles flame. As the flame burns bright we -

dialogues.text: (CRANE SHOT) We see Chris stop the Datsun in the middle of the desert road. We (CRANE?) DOWN to a close-up through the windshield. Chris looks left. Then, right. Into the rearview mirror, and suddenly turns the wheel, veering the Datsun off the paved highway into the vast desert. As we CRANE back UP, the Datsun moves into the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Datsun sits in the magical pastel twilight just before darkness slides over the desert. It is positioned at the foot of a wash wall that edges the soup bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Datsun, a yellow speck in the frame. Coyotes yap at the moon. Other than that, no sound on the desert floor. In the distance, voluptuous cumulonimbus clouds boil upward catching the last rosy glow of the west-setting sun over the rim of the upper Detrital watershed. We see strobe bursts of lightning followed by muffled thunder illuminating the thunder clouds from within. Short SERIES OF ANGLES as we MOVE IN on the distant gullies and ravines, starting to run with copious amounts of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris McCandless, in the same clothes he had been in back in the rooming house, sleeps in the back seat of the Datsun. His head supported by his backpack. We begin to HEAR a rumble. But this rumble is not thunder. It rapidly builds into an alarming ROAR. The roar grows to a deafening level. Chris awakens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he peeks up from the backseat looking forward through the windshield, he just barely catches sight of the leading edge of a flash flood. A four-foot high wall of water, mud and debris makes impact with the Datsun, momentarily enveloping it in water. Suddenly the car is SLAMMED against the cliff. CRACK! Chris sits upright, disoriented. POV: As far as the eye can see in the desert moonlight, water has taken over the desert with a flash flood. However, there's no panic in Chris' face as we observe him past a new crack in the wet windshield. The water, while violent seems to have topped off just above the wheels. Chris gets a slight smile on his face, as the car settles into its new position below the cliff. He returns to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What remains of Chris' travelling money burns in a pile beside the Datsun on the sun-lit but muddy desert floor. We follow a very long set of footprints (CAMERA TRACKING/TRUE VERTICAL) away from the burning cash through the mud, finally tilting up to the footprint maker, Chris. Slogging toward high ground. WIDE-SHOT: We see the abandoned Datsun nearly a mile behind Chris as he walks toward us wearing his backpack. He comes very close to camera (only a day or two's stubble on his face) and as we PAN him 180, we see as much wilderness before us as we did behind.

dialogues.text: Chris McCandless speaking to camera holds a microphone in a shadowy room, doing his Geraldo Rivera. It's tongue-in- cheek at best. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Emory University freshman Chris McCandless reporting from the vault at Thompson Hall. He indicates a hatchway in the floor leading to a brightly lit corridor below. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have just dynamited the hatchway and are the first human beings to step foot into this vault in over a hundred years. Somewhere in here lies the secret of the great beast within us all. A beast built on lies, corruption, and greed. We HEAR a GROWLING SOUND from behind Chris. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there it is! The legendary beast Mocra. CAMERA quickly PANS to a blanket-wrapped, crawling FELLOW STUDENT in a grotesque Halloween mask. We MOVE INTO CU on the monster growling. QUICK PAN back to Chris. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in mock fright) We've got to get out of here quick and re- secure the hatch while we make a plan of how to kill the beast. CAMERA SHAKES all over like a bad horror film trying to stay with Chris as he makes a quick escape down the hatchway into the University dorm corridor. CLUMSY VIDEO TIME CUT: Chris nailing the last nail in the hatchway from below. He climbs down the steps where he exchanges his hammer for his microphone from an off- camera source. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like we've succeeded - We HEAR the monster's GROWL from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - at least for the moment, in sealing the beast back into the vault. Your humble reporter, Chris McCandless will now struggle with the journalistic question of ethics: Will he retain his reporter's objectiveness or save the future of human truth by slaying this awful beast? He gives us a look of vaudevillian puzzlement - what will he do?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUE VIDEO
dialogues.text: We pick up with Chris in a corridor outside a door with a cheap paper-and-tape label announcing the adjacent room as the office of Ted Turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, your humble reporter Chris McCandless. We HEAR OS students commenting on Chris and his video crew:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Filmmaking 101?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point the camera at me. I'm a star. Chris speaking straight to camera, still tongue-in-cheek:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a Wizard of Oz tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay no attention to the voices behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FELLOW STUDENT PLAYING TED TURNER with obvious fake mustache is locked into an episode of Matlock on his television set as our bold reporter, Chris, barges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted! We've got a monster in the vault. It represents all the corruption, the deceit, and greed within us all. I must slay it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TED TURNER/STUDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worst acting we've ever seen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCandless, how many times have I had to tell you? I've had to tell you that you are a journalist and you can't get personally involved in your cases...or your stories. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted! I know how to kill it. And I'm the only one who knows. You can't keep sending me on stories and expecting me to do nothing! I look like some kind of an idiot. TED TURNER/STUDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who you're talking to?   I'm Ted Turner. Behind Chris in the corridor outside Ted's office, a PANICKED STUDENT arrives at the door. PANICKED STUDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCandless! You've got to hurry! The monster is scratching at the hatchway. He'll be out in no time. TED TURNER/STUDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threatening) It'll mean your job, Chris McCandless. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted) That's it, Ted. Fire me if you want but this beast must be slayed. Microphone in hand, Chris makes haste. The CAMERA RUNS WITH HIM out the door, through the corridor, up a set of steps to the hatchway. As he arrives, the monster appears above him in the hatchway crawl space having pulled off the board Chris had nailed. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into camera) This is the only thing that can kill the monster. It's gonna be risky but without great risk, there is no freedom. So we will now hear from the famous singer - Chris McCandless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piano is PUSHED INTO FRAME beside Chris. A YOUNG BLACK STUDENT pulls a stool in front of the piano and begins to play. Chris begins to serenade the monster, intermittently sharing the serenade directly into camera as well. He bursts into an uninhibited solo of Tender Is The Night. CAMERA TILTS UP to the monster looking out the hatchway, slowly dying from the song being sung. As the song continues to be sung and the monster continues to die, the AUDIO RECEDES and VIDEO IMAGES GO TO SLO MO. CARINE (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we were little, Chris was very to himself. He wasn't anti-social, he always had friends, and everybody liked him - but he could go off and entertain himself for hours, he didn't seem to need toys or friends. He could be alone without being lonely. The secrets our parents kept, though unknown to Chris and I, led to bouts of rage and even violence between them that we had been forced to witness since we were very young. It seemed like they never fought without us. I remember the first family meeting to let Chris and me in on their plans for getting a divorce. They wanted us to choose which of them we'd live with. I cried my eyes out. But the divorce never happened, though the threats and meetings never stopped. It wasn't long before Chris and I shut off -- we would tell mom and dad to go ahead and get the divorce. Chris and I just wanted to get away from their fights and mom kept promising to get out and take us with her as soon as their company made enough money. Dad had been the young genius [that] NASA enlisted to do [crucial] designs for the American satellite radar systems that would be our answer to the Russian Sputnik. And mom and he later started up a consulting firm combining her get-up- and-go resourcefulness with his wealth of knowledge. By the time the company actually made its first million, the careerism and money seemed to erase her memory of the promise she'd made us. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this is when Chris began to see "careers" as a diseased invention of the twentieth century and to resent money and the useless priority people made of it in their lives. He'd begun planning to "slay the beast"...to make himself free.

dialogues.text: Chris is behind the cafe beside a pair of dumpsters. He removes the Datsun's license plates from his backpack and discards them deeply into the garbage.

dialogues.text: Toward the end of June, Chris had mailed our parents his final grade report. Walt and Billie open the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost all A's. "A" in Apartheid in South African Society and History of Anthropological Thought; A- in Contemporary African Politics and the Food Crisis in Africa; and on it went. Clever boy, my brother. We observe Carine in a delicate afternoon light. She is sitting up on her bed with an unread book, looking out the window toward us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But by the end of July we hadn't heard anything from him and my parents were getting very worried. Carine's POV:   Walt with his arm around Billie in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris had never had a phone, so they decided to drive down to Atlanta and surprise him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, backpack on, walking away from camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Walt and Billie's car pass under an Atlanta mileage sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they arrived at the apartment, there was a "For Rent" sign in his window, and the manager told my parents that Chris had moved out at the end of June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We observe Walt and Billie chatting with Chris' apartment manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they got home, I had to hand them all the letters they had sent Chris that summer which had been returned in a bundle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bundle of letters are splayed out on the kitchen table - "Return to Sender" stamps visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris had instructed the post office to hold them until August 1st so that mom and dad wouldn't know that anything was up. Some part of me understood what he had done. That he had spent the previous four years fulfilling an absurd and onerous duty in graduating from college. We return to the image of Carine sitting on her bed as she plops on Chris' old graduation cap. We slowly ZOOM IN on her throughout the remaining V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, at last he was unincumbered. Emancipated from the stifling world of parents and peers. Abstraction, security, and material excess. Those things that cut Chris off from the raw truth of his existence. I only hoped he was safe...and I missed him.

dialogues.speaker: OF THE SCALE AND POWER OF THIS LANDSCAPE.
dialogues.text: TRACKING SHOT (GROUND LEVEL): CLOSE ON Chris, surrounded by a summit grove embraced in its nature. ANGLE: A DEER drinking from a creek, pops its head up between trees and scrub, watching the alien human pass. An EAGLE soars above (perhaps it was this POV represented in our helicopter shot) WATER babbling in a mountain creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: Chris -   In his eyes we see the landscape inject itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEQUENCE: Chris makes camp beside a stream pulling a sack of rice from his backpack and cooking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped in his own "The Good, The Bad, And The Ugly" poncho, Chris eats rice while crouched beside a campfire reading from Jack London's White Fang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is on the move north through the gorgeous landscape of the Sierras, humming as he walks, when he comes upon a sign on the trail: PERMIT CAMPING IN DESIGNATED CAMPGROUNDS ONLY. Chris bows to the sign as one would to speak to a small child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign, sign. Everywhere a sign. Fuckin' up the scenery, breakin' my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do this. Don't do that. Can't you read the sign? And then, very impulsively, he karate kicks the sign off its post into a log collapsing into ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burning log collapses in Chris' campfire, reduced to glowing embers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is awakened by the SOUND of TWIGS SNAPPING in a nearby thicket. He quickly grabs a knife from his backpack, unzips six inches of the tent door open. We see his eyes peering out. The CRACKLING moves closer. His grip on the knife tightens. Suddenly a hot white light hits his face.   And a VOICE comes from behind the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.S. Forestry. Could you step out of the tent please? Now we see the FOREST RANGER appear from the thicket. Chris exits the tent, catching himself holding the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he drops the knife to the ground)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I thought you were a bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you. You're less than a hundred yards from the nearest den. That's why I came over here to talk to you. Do you have some identification?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm sorry. My name's Alex. I've been travelling a lot and I got robbed and my identification was taken. FOREST RANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind if I take a look in your tent? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. The Forest Ranger bends over. Pops his flashlight through the tent door and peers around a bit before re- addressing Chris. FOREST RANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the character who knocked down our sign, are ya? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggles) No. FOREST RANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there was a sign indicating that camping was allowed by permit only. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't have a permit. FOREST RANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sure you don't. Listen, it looks like you've got your food secured pretty good, so I'm not gonna make you move on tonight. But, these bears out here are nursing young and you know how that goes. Next time, stop at the Rangers station and get yourself a permit. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I appreciate it. I'm gonna be headed towards the coast tomorrow. FOREST RANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful. They shake hands and the Forest Ranger disappears into the thicket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris descends the mountains where they meet the Redwoods. Every perilous step creates a mini landslide down the hill; dirt and gravel. Chris stops briefly to observe an over-flying commercial airliner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking imaginary conversation among passengers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a man mommy? That's no mere man, sweetheart. That's Alexander SuperTramp! King of the wild frontier! Chris briefly waves to the airplane above and continues his descent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car slows to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where I turn off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright man.    Thanks a lot. Chris is dropped off. The driver veers off the highway and into the distance. Chris is left behind to hitch another ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is across the road from Chris as one by one cars pass him by. He turns to move north by foot and we track with him, his back to oncoming traffic, he continues to hitchhike with an extended thumb. Something catches his eye in the treeline beside the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE: Chris, moving to the mysterious object. As he lifts it, we see that it is a goofy looking straw hat. He dusts it off, and snugs it onto his head, when a police car comes into frame and stops beside Chris. With a quick blast of the siren, Chris turns to regard the police car. The POLICEMAN gets out of the car and moves to Chris. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doin' this evening? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) I'm alright. What's the matter? POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna put your backpack down on the hood of my car. Chris does not oblige.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I asked you to, sir. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I haven't done anything wrong.   These are my personal items. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that it's unlawful to hitchhike on this stretch of highway. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see a safe area for a vehicle to stop? We got a tree-lined highway without a substantial shoulder here. And we've had a lot of accidents on this road from people stopping in the traffic lane for hitchhikers. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, but...I mean, you stopped your car. You're in the traffic lane. And you can see, there's hardly any cars out here. Plus, it's a straight road; you can see for a long ways. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disbelief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's really been accidents along here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see some identification? Now Chris is worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have any identification? Chris shakes his head "No."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling out a ticket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm gonna site you for unlawful hitchhiking. You don't have to appear. You can send a check directly to the Humboldt County Clerks Office for restitution. If you don't pay it within 30 days, you're subject to fine and warrant. I'm gonna trust that you're gonna give me accurate information. What's your name? Chris can't bring himself to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCandless. Christopher Johnson McCandless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, Billie, and Carine sit around the kitchen table in August. A copy of Chris' ticket has been sent to the Annandale address and sits before them. Billie and Carine sit silently. Walt's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Chris were trying to disappear, it would have been a pretty uncharacteristic lapse for him to give the police his real place of residence. Though my parents had already contacted the Annandale police with their initial concerns, this ticket arriving from California made them frantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father called one of his old government friends who put him in touch with a private investigator, someone who'd done work with the DIA and the CIA. Using the Willow Creek ticket as a starting point, the investigator began chasing down leads. Most of them led far afield -- to Europe and South Africa. Ultimately turning up nothing. What my dad couldn't believe was that he'd given up his car. He seemed to love that Datsun so much. It sounded just like Chris to me, though. He was very much of the school that you should own nothing except what you could carry on your back at a dead run.

dialogues.speaker: SOUTH OF THE OREGON LINE
dialogues.text: With his backpack lunging and a free hand holding his goofy new hat onto his head, we find Chris at a "dead run" to catch a ride that had overshot him. (Director's note: Don't leave this image too soon.) An old van idles waiting for him. As he gets to the passenger side, the woman passenger gets out. This is JAN BURRES, early 40's, looks to be still on the long road home from Woodstock. A little heavyset, dark wavy hair with a lot of premature grey in it. Jan moving to the side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. We just barely saw you there, under that crazy hat of yours. We couldn't back up - the van's reverse is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Jan fiddles with side door handle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   That's okay. Thanks for stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This door's a little tricky, I'll get it. And with a little pulling, it opens. Indicating the pony- tailed and bearded driver (RAINEY), early 50's, definitely Woodstock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hop in, that's Rainey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm Rainey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm Jan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rainey.    Hi Jan.    I'm Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex of the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing the side door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jan jumps back in passenger seat and the van rolls on. 39   INT. RAINEY & JAN VAN 3-SHOT - CHRIS BETWEEN THEM IN THE BACKSEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you out there a long time hitching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of days. But sometimes I forget to put my thumb out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably, the rest of the time, that hat scares `em away. Chris checks himself in the rearview mirror and gets a kick out of what he sees (That hat's staying on.) Jan is looking at the rearview mirror too, observing Chris with mild concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you ate something? Chris pulls out a bag of berries and edible plants he's collected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that? I've got this book and it shows you all the plants and berries that are edible. You can find things wherever you go. Jan steals a glance to Rainey.      He's hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just in town getting some beads and stuff. Jan does handicrafts, so we're usually going from one swap meet to another. She's so good at what she does, we sold everything. So, we set up camp at Orick Beach. You're welcome to camp there with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eat there with us. Chris is beaming at the thought of real food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, Jan, and Rainey are beside a campfire, sitting on blankets. Their tents loom behind them. Jan is weaving some sort of craft art. Chris is chomping on chicken and beans like they're going out of style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between large swallows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I just left the car. It was a great car too. I'd driven it cross country the first time when I got out of high school. I had some really great adventures with it. That thing would just go and go. I mean, it was an `82 but if I'd kept it, it would've lasted me forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're a leather now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a leather? Rainey nods, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking to Jan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a leather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a leather tramp. That's what they call the ones that hoof it on foot. So, we're technically rubber tramps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjecting) As we have a vee-hi-cle. Rainey makes a move to put his arm around Jan. She goes a little stiff and fends it off. Chris notices. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex could have a vehicle. If he didn't burn his money. Why would you want to do that? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need money.   It makes people cautious. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little irritated) Well, you have to be a little cautious Alex. That book of yours is all well and fine but you can't depend entirely on leaves and berries. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you'd want to depend on much more than that. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your mom and dad? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makin' their money somewhere. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Chris. You look like a loved             * kid. Be fair.                                    * CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair? JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll paraphrase Thoreau -- "Rather than          * love, than money, than fairness, give me         * truth."                                          * RAINEY                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like shit.   There's the truth.         * They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits up reading, his tent entry flap ajar to let the small candle lantern ventilate. OS we HEAR a ZIPPING SOUND. It's Rainey. We see him from Chris' POV coming out of his tent deep in thought. As he moves to the glowing embers of what remains of the campfire, Rainey's face goes out of frame and all Chris can see are his booted feet, tapping bits of glowing wood into the center of the fire. The tapping is slow and thoughtful. Micro-embers float upward into the night. Chris' tent flap closes by his own hand. ANGLE: Chris' dog-ears his book and puts out the lantern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Chris foraging for firewood in the bluffs above the beach. He's got it tied to his back and his front. If we didn't know better, we'd think he was camouflaging himself. Chris' POV: The rocks beside the water's edge. We see Rainey sitting beside the water, staring out to sea. We follow Chris' gaze to Jan, some fifty yards down the beach, walking melancholically in the opposite direction of Rainey. ANGLE: Rainey at the water's edge.   Chris appears beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regarding Chris wrapped up in wood)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez. If I struck a match to you, I'd have warmth and dinner at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Rainey's humor does not hide an inner turmoil. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jan going? RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my friend, all is not well on the hippie front. Chris pulls out his pocketknife, cuts the twine that binds the firewood to his body, and takes a seat beside Rainey. RAINEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an industrious little fucker, aren't ya... Yeah, it's funny how things happen at particular times. I've loved that woman for a lot of years. But you know, she's got a...story. We've been going through this thing real quietly cause, well...So, after running into you last night, this thing we were going through quietly, she started talking about. You know what I mean? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think what? Chris is looking off at Jan walking in the distance. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's probably quietly disconnecting. It doesn't feel right to her to be close to you if there's a hole of some kind somewhere else. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a helluva insight. Jesus!... You're not Jesus, are you? You gonna walk on that water and get her back for me? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm a little afraid of water. Rainey gives him a sideways glance. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. But it's something I've got to get over sometime. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'll swim in it if you'll carry the firewood back to the campsite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll carry.   Shit-yes I'll carry. And with that, Chris runs down the beach toward Jan. Rainey watches Chris and Jan chat briefly. Then they strip down to their underwear and jump into the ocean, splashing and laughing. ANGLE: Rainey. A warmth comes over him, watching his old lady having some fun. He grabs two armfuls of wood and heads to the campsite. ANGLE: Chris and Jan swimming in the chilly water, having a ball. Jan increasingly indulges herself a motherly closeness and joy with Chris. And Chris allows it. She pushes the stringy hairs from his eyes, worries when he descends below the surface for too many seconds, and smiles and laughs in tender relief when from below surface one of her toes is pulled on by the big fish Chris. As he re- surfaces, she gives him a splash right in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a burning campfire in the late afternoon, we see the chilly bodies of Chris and Jan carrying their clothes run shivering toward us. Rainey sits beside the campfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you guys might need a little heat. Jan smiles appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to Rainey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not hot enough. Put your arms around me. As they embrace, Chris throws a coat on from his tent, puts on his funny straw hat, and grabs a book. Rainey has wrapped a blanket around Jan and they sit beside the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go down the beach a ways and read a little bit. I'll bring the rest of that wood back before nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. We might take a run into town to grab some food for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good. He heads off down the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC OVER
dialogues.text: 1. The ocean moving toward sunset. 2. Seagulls, gliding inches over the water. 3. The breeze on the sea grass. 4. Chris in his big hat reading at water's edge. 5. Jan and Rainey deeply engaged in conversation beside the fire. 6. Chris closing his book, remaining meditative at water's edge. 7. Jan and Rainey in town, buying groceries and being playful with each other. 8. OVER Chris' shoulder, the sun sets and day becomes night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan and Rainey on a blanket sharing a joint. Chris lying beside the campfire in his sleeping bag. Jan takes a toke, passes the joint to Rainey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Alex ought to do, Rainey? He ought to come out to the Slabs this winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Rainey takes a toke on the joint. RAINEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd like that if you're still on the road. Lot of fellow travelers. Rainey offers the joint to Chris.   Chris passes it up with a hand gesture. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that? The Slabs? RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's down in Niland, California.   You know where the Salton Sea is? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near San Diego, yeah? RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well about 200 miles Northeast of there, but yeah. Niland's off the east shore of Salton. Wild place. The navy bulldozed and abandoned a base there. All that's left is a grid of concrete foundations. They're scattered over about a square mile or so. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the weather turns cold across the rest of the country, people show up there by the thousands: snow birds... RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drifters... JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sundry vagabonds... RAINEY / JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like ourselves. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livin' on the cheap under the sun. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sell your handcrafts there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. And a lot of second-hand goods. There's a swap meet. The people are cool. There's even some kids running around sometimes. Most everyone there, if they're not avoiding the cold, are at least dodging the IRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the FBI.   CIA! DDT!!! The three of them laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good. You should check it out. If you come, I'll make a proper hat for you. (standing, shaking out her blanket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Alex. I'm gonna clean up and the old man and I are gonna get some rest. (indicating the sleeping bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you got yourself a good bag there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...my mother made it from a kit. Jan sees an almost imperceptible mother pang in Chris, but he pushes it away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna sleep out here by the fire.     I want to read a little bit. Jan moves to Chris, hugs him, kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wonderful.   Don't make me worry about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is burning low. Chris reads from Thoreau's WALDEN from the chapter on "Higher Laws" as we move slowly in toward him, we begin to HEAR quiet sounds of what may be love-making coming from Rainey and Jan's tent. A gentle smile comes over Chris' face and in its irony, he looks to the page before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris' sliding fingertip underlines the following passage: Chastity is the flowering of a man; and what are called genius, heroism, holiness, and the like, are but various fruits which succeed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gulls pierce into the grey morning ocean, snapping from schools of fish. And the subtle crackling of a campfire's death. There on the beach, Jan and Rainey's van, their tent, and the fireless coals of last night. But no sign of Chris, his bag or his tent. Jan appears from her tent, rubbing her eyes. She wears a sarong which she re-secures at the breast, then notices that Chris has left. But where his tent had been, the words:

dialogues.speaker: THANK YOU JAN AND RAINEY
dialogues.text: are spelled out in the sand with bits of driftwood. CU: Jan - We see her sadness. Rainey appears at her shoulder. He understands what is inside his woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reminded me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Go to WIDE SHOT: Jan and Rainey remaining as they were. FOREGROUND: Seagulls GLIDE THROUGH FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC OVER: Joe Henry's King's Highway

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1. Chris hitchhiking through the Sage Brush Uplands 2. Chris squatting over a water bucket, shaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3. Camping in the lava beds of the Columbia River Basin. 4. Walking across the Idaho Panhandle. 5. Cooking the last of his rice on the Montana border. 6. Hitchhiking in the Montana sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Chris hitching down a lonely two-lane road surrounded by fields and distant mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In early September, mom and dad got a call from the Annandale police notifying them that Chris' abandoned car had been identified by the Arizona Highway Patrol after a group of rare flower hunters stumbled upon it in the desert. There were no signs that Chris had intended to return to it. But there wasn't any evidence of struggle. The police said they thought Chris had chosen to leave it behind and not that it had been taken from him. Nonetheless, the initial comfort that gave mom and dad, quickly turned to their realization that Chris was actually trying not to be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Walt. He walks out the door of his house into the street. He keeps walking. And we go with him in his silent but internal Armageddon. We PULL him in CU throughout all that follows...(Refer to SCENE 171: "Dad calls it `suspended animation.'" This may affect our visual approach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The year Chris graduated high school he bought the Datsun, used. He wanted to drive it cross-country and visit our old neighborhood in California. The day before he left was my dad's birthday. Chris made a speech...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands beside the family piano, speaking to a party of his parent's friends, Walt and Billie among them. Beside him, a large gift-wrapped present. Carine sits at the foot of the stairs at the back of the room watching her brother with a hint of concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little drunk, a little emotional)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you and I have had our differences over the years...but on your birthday I want to tell you how grateful I am for all the things you've given me. And that you did it starting from nothing to working your way through college and busting your ass to support us kids. So, in return, I've been busting my ass a bit...at Domino's Pizza - Chris moves to the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and I've gotten you this token, this damned expensive token, as a token of that appreciation. Chris holds the large gift toward Walt. Walt moves through his friends to Chris and strips the paper, exposing a beautiful Questar Telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting his son the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you look at that. Walt holds the telescope up for all to see.   And the party responds with applause. Chris walks through the cheering family friends to take his place beside Carine at the bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you must've had a lot to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much and not enough. I used to believe all that stuff. That whole story. I thought maybe if I said it again, I'd believe it. But I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears have come to Chris' eyes. He puts his head in his hands. Carine puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ANNANDALE STREET
dialogues.text: PRESENT:   Walt expressionless, walking into camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day after the party, Chris left on his trip and ended up staying away most of the summer. It was nearly three months before he walked back into our house in Annandale. He had a scruffy beard, his hair was long and tangled, and he was rail thin. As soon as I heard he was home, I ran into his room to talk to him. In California, he'd looked up some old family friends who still lived there. He'd found out that long after he had been born, our dad had continued a relationship with his first wife Marcia in secret.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CUT BANK, MONTANA
dialogues.text: BRIEF CUTAWAY to Chris hitching on the Montana highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that one lie had led to another. That two years after Chris was born, dad had had another son with Marcia. Worse yet was that it was Marcia to whom he was still legally married at the time. And it was Chris and I who were the bastard children.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ANNANDALE STREET
dialogues.text: Walt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's arrogance made him conveniently oblivious to the pain he caused. And mom, in the shame and embarrassment of a young mistress, became his accomplice.

dialogues.speaker: CARINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She and my dad had decided to bend the truth about this other child saying that dad wasn't the father and they maintained that their fraudulent marriage was real. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CARINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chris was quiet when he told me this. He said it made his "entire childhood seem like a fiction"; that "the truth had been dying everyday." If something bothered Chris, he'd usually keep it to himself. And he made me promise to do the same. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never did tell mom and dad that he knew. But Chris measured himself and those around him by an impossibly rigorous moral code. He loathed what he considered mom and dad's hypocrisy and resented what they considered guidance. Chris submitted to dad's authority through college but I knew he raged inwardly the whole time. It was inevitable that Chris would rebel. And when he did, he did it with characteristic immoderation. Walt suddenly collapses to his knees weeping, heartbroken and ashamed on a quiet Annandale street in the shadowless light of dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father is a brilliant man. But he had made some terrible mistakes. And to some extent, it seemed Chris was making him pay an awful price. The image of Walt DISSOLVES INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pick-up truck pulls over for Chris. As Chris jumps in, we see on the passenger side door, the name WAYNE WESTERBERG boldly painted across it. Chris hops in beside a hyper kinetic man with thick shoulders and a black goatee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling a cigarette without moving forward with the truck, his knees rattling up and down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doing? Wayne Westerberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Wayne. Alex McCandless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like every time I come on this road, there's somebody hitching out here who looks as skinny and unfed as you. Chris nods with a laugh.   Wayne continuing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I gotta stop in Ethridge to drop something off (know what I mean?) Chris is not sure about the "drop something off" part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How `bout you and I grab something to eat down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't want to burden you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been since you've had anything to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of days. I kinda ran out of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's no choice about it.    I'm gonna get you some dinner. Wayne lights his cigarette, puts the truck in gear and they head down the road. As the sun dips behind the horizon we TILT UP off the departing truck to the sky. Ominously mounting clouds stunningly reflect the red rays of the hidden sun:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne's truck cuts through a track in a wheat field moving toward a compound of three trailers, one a double- wide, the other two on wheels, smaller. Beside them, a Wyeth-esque farmhouse. He eases the engine and comes to a stop in front of the double-wide. As he and Chris dismount the truck, Wayne gives him a hushing finger across the lips. They tip-toe up to the door, where Wayne shuffles a bunch of keys. A little thunder kicking in the distant sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Wayne and Chris enter, they tip-toe over empty booze bottles and passed out work crew; Wayne's harvesting team. They make their way to a small table in the kitchenette. Remains of the evening's dinner are on the stove. Wayne turns on the stovetop coils to heat it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where is it you're headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about doubling back through the Canadian side of Glacier Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I used to have a girlfriend who'd go there, camp on the Black Feet Res. She was into all that American Indian stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAYNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can bring you to the border at Sweet Grass once you've had some food. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that'd be great.   What do you do out here? WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I do a lot of things. Computer programming. Video game repair. I'm a licensed pilot, own a grain elevator in Carthage and another one a few miles out of town. But in the summertime I run a combine crew, follow the harvest from Texas way the hell north to the Canadian border. We just got done cutting barley for Coors and Anheuser Busch. But then I got this little black box deal on the side (You know what I mean?) CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean those free satellite TV deals? WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though he hadn't brought it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it, not me. Chris is dazzled by this renaissance man of the plains. Wayne stands to dish out a couple of plates of heated food. As Chris starts digging in, a major gust of wind rocks the trailer. WAYNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, responding to wind) OOOOOOH. Chris doesn't respond, digs into the food. Points to the unconscious tribe splayed out. SIX GERMANIC-LOOKING UNCONSCIOUS BODIES. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these guys? Wayne gets a little giggle. WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my Hudderites. Agriculture's a pretty transient business. These guys come off the Hudderite colony looking for work. I always got work for people. Then that guy - (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at guy making most of his snore)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Kevin. He's with me most of the time. He's not a Hudderite. He's from Madison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madison.    Okay. Just then, the rain kicks in full gear outside, pounding the trailer shell. A couple hits of lightning follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you don't want to go out there on the road tonight. Why don't you just roll your sleeping bag out and play like a Hudderite until morning. Chris looks about. There's not much room but it beats the pelting outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Wayne. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, with a grin on his face, lays in his sleeping bag between a Hudderite and the sleeping KEVIN. Wayne comes from the back bedroom, tip-toes through the sleeping bodies to hand Chris a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a good sleep. See you in the morning. Chris waves a thanks, puts the pillow beneath his head and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are TIGHT on Chris' hand atop the shifter of one of Wayne's lumbering harvesters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now take hold of the joystick, get the feel of header, idle it down with the toggle switch... As Chris makes the attempt, we immediately hear the grinding of gears, the instrument alarms in chaos. WIDE SHOT: Chris and Wayne sit atop a combine. In the background we see Wayne's trailer and two other combines piloted by Wayne's crew members on the ocean of ripe blond grain. Chris tries his hand at the shifter once more.   This tim the thing starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. That's it. Now take it on out and make yourself some money. Wayne jumps off the combine and Chris begins to cut his pattern, intermittently struggling with the shifter. Wayne laughs his ass off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SUNBURST
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS indicating a SERIES OF DAYS passing as Chris gets a hang of the machines a little more at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six men including Wayne and Chris, two among them - Hudderites, crowd in to the small dinner area of the trailer. Talking politics and bullshit, and eating a welcome meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna break out some whiskey. Alex, you want anything other than that beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take a White Russian if you've got it. The group of men laugh at the youngster's order of a fancy drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you Alex, a Commie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just like White Russians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got anything like that here. But I tell ya what. And I know I speak for everybody. You wanna come work with us in Carthage, we'll hook you up on the grain elevator and get you a White Russian down at the Cabaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn tomorrow, engines roaring. (to the others like a mock blues singer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pot o Gold. Oh that pot o gold." They all join in to the chant/song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pot o Gold.    Gotta get that pot o gold!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his beer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Carthage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Carthage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGIC HOUR. TELEPHOTO LENS. The harvesting convoy rolls toward us like a herd of mammoths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of silent, quaint establishing tableaus. (Director's Note:    Condor above street) It's a sleepy little town. Population: 274. Cluster of clapboard houses, tiny yards, and weathered brick storefronts rising humbly from the immensity of the northern plains. Stately rows of cottonwoods shade a grid of streets, seldom disturbed by moving vehicles. From UNDER CAMERA, the series of tableaus is interrupted as the convoy roars into our frame from BENEATH CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the passenger seat, Chris is glowing at his new surroundings. Wayne picks up the CB radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Kevin, get all the machines back to the elevator. I'm gonna show Chris to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over CB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got dibs on that shower, that shower's all me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First come, first serve buddy. Wayne signs off and veers off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-story Victorian in the Queen Anne style. Wayne veers his truck into the front yard, parking under the big cottonwood that towers above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris follows Wayne up the narrow stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carrying Chris' pack for him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on up in here. This'll be your room for as long as you hang about. Wayne opens the door at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne plops Chris' pack beside a single bed in the tiny but comfortable room. Chris enters, very happy with his new quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shower's down the hall. If you hurry you can beat the rest of the boys to it. But you do want to grab a shower cause we're all heading over to the Cabaret in exactly thirty-six minutes. So, get your dancing shoes on. There's foo-foo in the medicine cabinet. I think it's Brut. (slaps his own face as if he's putting on cologne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you want to put your charm in overdrive cause we like to PAH-TAY! Wayne gives Chris a wink and exits, shutting the door behind him. Chris takes in his new surroundings. He's on a work crew and he likes it. Chris makes the move for the shower but by the time he opens his door to the hall, all the other crew members are barreling up the stairs in front of them, clamoring for dibs (Chris' POV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a kid voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had first last night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering the bathroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you wanna wash my back, cowboy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go ahead, fairy.    Just don't use all the soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: Chris. He gets a kick out of these guys.    He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jack Daniels is flowing. Wayne's crew drinks, smokes, and strikes out with every fat woman in the place. GAIL BORAH, an on-again, off-again girlfriend of Wayne's tends bar. A petite sad-eyed woman, slight as a heron, delicate features and long blond hair. Wayne and Chris sit at the end of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, this is Gail . This is the one to go to for that White Russian you've been wanting. Of course the quid pro quo can be hazardous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Wayne. (to Chris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a White Russian, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please, ma'am? Wayne slaps Chris on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't he great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay any attention to him. With that Wayne reaches over the bar, grabs Gail and gets her in a lip-lock, to which she ultimately gives in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne and Chris are both drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything to do with hunting, preserving the meat, smoking it or whatever, you talk to Kevin over there. That's your man. ANGLE: KEVIN.   He looks every bit the Grizzly Adams part WAYNE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outdoors-man. What's the interest in all that? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking about going to Alaska. WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska, Alaska? Or city Alaska?     The city Alaska does have markets. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a drunken, excited energy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Alaska, Alaska. I want to be all the way out there. On my own. No map. No watch. No axe. Just out there. Big mountains, rivers, sky. Game. Just be out there in it. In the wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wild. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe write a book about my travels. About getting out of this sick society. WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughing) Society, right. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you know what I don't understand? I don't understand why, why people are so bad to each other, so often. It just doesn't make any sense to me. Judgement. Control. All that. WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who "people" we talking about? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, parents and hypocrites. Politicians and pricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is clearly troubled by his own words.      Wayne le into Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping a long finger against Chris' forehead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a mistake. It's a mistake to get too deep into that kind of stuff. Alex, you're a helluva young guy, but I promise you this: You're a young guy. Blood and fire! You're juggling blood and fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chimes in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you to be giving advice to anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood and fire...What? Mr. Happy. That's who I am. Gimme a kiss. Gail    pushes him off with mock disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock opening his zipper, in a high-pitched voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, give Mr. Happy a kiss! On the television above the bar appears Reverend Jesse Jackson. We can't hear him but we can see him. Chris points at the television and yells out to the entire bar of cowboys and ranch hands -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's who could be President! Wayne buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is sacked out from his night of drinking when -

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: The door knocks blast into Chris' head. He awakens to Wayne opening his bedroom door. Wayne, despite his own drinking the night before, is wide awake and fresh as a daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workin' time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the boys are hard at it, including Chris and Wayne. Wayne moves to Chris' side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you think about all this? (The working life)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Wayne and most of the crew get a little rest in the shade of the grain elevator and eat their lunches, Chris and Kevin are deep in a bald patch in the field. Kevin is taking Chris through the paces of smoking and curing meat in the wilds. Chris listens and takes notes. (Director's note: Cast a "Kevin" who knows this shit and shoot it as a dialogue scene as well as a silent tableau.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed and Chris is taking over the piano, surprising everyone with a tremendous talent. Segueing from honky-tonk country to ragtime, he's become the life of the party. The MUSIC continues OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men of Wayne's crew (who by now we've come to know) and Chris are working their asses off. POST LAP MUSIC FADES OUT as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the crew at work with a SERIES OF MYSTERY ANGLES: Tires kicking up dust on dirt roads, through town, and into the field behind the grain elevator. Back to the work, back to the tires. Back to the work, back to these several cars hauling ass through the field. Back to Wayne, up high in the grain elevator - WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chris, as he lowers himself down the man-lift)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta take a piss. Chris' POV: from high in the grain elevator. He watches Wayne below, as Wayne saunters out to the field to take a piss. With his back to us, Wayne whips it out and starts pissing about 25 yards from the grain elevator. CU Wayne. He looks up from his urination, the grain elevator behind him. We see a slight mischievous smile come to his face. He puts his hands up into the air when suddenly - Six unmarked FBI vehicles surround him. (Director's note: Triangulate three long lenses on Wayne as the mysterious cars enter each frame, as they skid to a dusty stop on all sides of him.) Chris and the men of his crew look on. MAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned him about those little black boxes. As Wayne is handcuffed and led away, he nods up to his boys. WAYNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to arresting agent) You wanna get that zipper for me? (and then calling out to his crew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry boys. Gonna have to shut down for a while. Alex! You come back and work for me anytime. (to Chris and the men) Gail's got all your checks, guys. I shouldn't be away too long. With that, the FBI agents have hustled the good-natured Wayne into the back of one of the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they take off into the distance, we move in on Chris, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pre-lap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits at the end of the bar with Gail Borah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking a lot about Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska? What kind of nut-nut are you? Alex, it's October for Christ's sake. You go to Alaska, you go in the Spring. This time of year you wanna head south. Personally, I like Las Vegas. One-armed bandit. That's what I like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe I ought to put off going to Alaska, at least so I can get settled up there in decent weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South. You want to go south. You want me to take you out to the highway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting on his cowboy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little lady, I walked in, I can walk out. He puts a few bills down on the bar, saddles up his backpack, and gives Gail a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care of yourself now, Alex. You got a whole family here depending on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. Thanks Gail .   And tell Wayne, I'll drop him a line. He gives her a kiss on the cheek and he's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty Carthage streets but for Christopher Johnson McCandless walking off as we CRANE UP.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (OCTOBER 28 1990)
dialogues.text: Chris has hitched a ride with a long-haul trucker. SERIES OF ANGLES: MUSIC OVER: Traveling shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris disembarks the long-haulers truck, waves a goodbye, and the truck moves on. SERIES OF ANGLES: Chris walking south through the desert following the river bank. He covers twelve miles before he arrives in an Arizona town, a dusty weigh-in station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town is quiet but along the storefront lane where Chris walks, he comes upon a sporting goods store. In the window, a fiberglass river kayak. Chris stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR passing cars humming above. Chris has set up camp and he's digging in the dirt. He buries many of his belongings. He makes sure he's got his check from working with Wayne in his pocket. He packs only the essential items, burying all else. He gets into his sleeping bag and goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris backpacks past the mushroom rock forms at the entrance of Lee's Ferry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris approaches the GREEN-SUITED FUNCTIONARY at the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. If I wanted to paddle down the river, where's the best place to launch out of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To launch out of?" What's your experience level?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any?   Do you have a permit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A permit for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't paddle down the river without a permit. If you like, you can apply for one here, get yourself some experience, and I'll put you on the wait-list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait-list?   To paddle down a river?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how long do you have to wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an opening May 2003.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you could always join a commercial raft trip and go with a licensed guide. They usually have a few last minute cancellations. I think it's about two- thousand dollars. Chris busts a gut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help. The Green Suit eyes Chris' departure with suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands beside a dramatic section of rapids.    The whitewater roars. As we SLOWLY ZOOM INTO Chris' face, terrified and absorbed by the torrent, a bead of sweat drops across his forehead, TILTS OUR CAMERA to his trembling hands and legs, when Peter Gabriel's I Have The Touch begins to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM INTO Chris' face...a decision: Fear becomes determination We SMASH CUT ON CUE with Peter Gabriel's vocals. SLO MO, SUPER DRAMATIC - Chris blasting out of a shoot in the rapids in the kayak we saw the night before. It's outrageous. Hair-raising. Just like Peter Gabriel sings it, he has the touch. This kid's never kayaked before, certainly never on rapids. But it's that immortal stage of life, no care, no helmet, no life-jacket, pure adrenaline. He can hardly believe he's surviving it as he goes but there's no looking back now. And with every thump of the music, we share his rush. His pure unadulterated exhilaration. With the culmination of the music, Chris has successfully shot the rapid. He paddles through quiet waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move in on him as he maneuvers the kayak to face upstream. There before him, the impossible rapid he had just completed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Superman. SuperTramp. He feels immortal. He makes his about-face and is about to head down stream when he sees at the river's edge, a group of RIVER TOURISTS and their GUIDE lunching beside a pontoon raft. The tourists look like a bunch of bewildered tubby-troopers in their misfitted orange life- vests and cereal bowl helmets. The RIVER GUIDE yells out at Chris as Chris moves PAST CAMERA and away. The guide gets on his satellite phone to alert the Rangers. We ZOOM SLOWLY away from them toward the rapid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip Glass' Cloudscape plays OVER:   Chris paddles on. LOW ANGLE: It is a narrow gorge of solid rock, looking up from hundreds of feet below the canyon crest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canyon has widened to beach-like banks.   Music FADES Along the banks he sees a YOUNG BLONDE COUPLE. This is MADS and SONJA, in their 20's, Danish. They play at the river's edge beside their campsite, hotdogs cooking on a Hibachi. Chris averts his eyes when Sonja rises from the water, topless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling out to Chris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can join us! Chris doesn't know quite what to do. But Mads seems quite comfortable inviting a stranger into the presence of his topless girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have hotdogs! Chris - can't turn that down!   He paddles to within feet of the water's edge. MADS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Mads. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Alex. SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Sonja. Chris gives Sonja a little wave. She bypasses it, wading up to the Kayak, giving him a big hug. SONJA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Alex. This couple is extremely energetic. Can't wait to please. And a bona fide American adventurer in their midst. It's everything they could've wanted. MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are from Copenhagen.   And you are from the rapids. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Got! MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy man. You're a crazy man!    Sonja, he is a crazy man. (to Chris) I'll make you a hotdog. Mads grabs a hotdog from the Hibachi. MADS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one minute. One minute... Sonja has moved to the tent to put on a dry T-shirt. But as she moves back to the water's edge, those nipples keep saying Hello. Chris, meanwhile, simply cannot wipe the smile off his face in the presence of these warm, open people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this. Don't you love this? This is nature. We see it in the American movies. How come you're crazy? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Because that's crazy! You come down the rapids. What do you want on your hotdog? Mustard and relish? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have ketchup? MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have mustard and relish. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mustard and relish it is then. MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonja, you want a hotdog? SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Danish) Of course I want a hotdog.   Why are you stupid? Mads plops two more hotdogs onto the grill. MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating) She asked me why I'm stupid. And I say, well...like I ask you why you're crazy and you say "well." Where are you going? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't decided. MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We like it here very much. We went to Los Angeles. And then, we went to Las Vegas. SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Las Vegas is very nice.   The universe is very good.

dialogues.speaker: MADS
dialogues.text: And then, we come here.   Maybe you go to Mexico. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take kayak around Lake Mead and then take the river down to Mexico. Chris likes the idea. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far are we from Lake Mead? MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonja, how far is Hoover Dam? Sonja grabs a map from the tent, opens and scrutinizes it. We follow her finger tracing the river. SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe three hundred thirty kilometers...like two hundred miles. Sonja walks the map over to Chris at water's edge and hands it to him. He studies it. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I wonder if I could go all the way down into the Gulf of California. Chris traces his finger along the impossibly long route leading to El Golfo de Santa Clara. MADS
