dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering the water with Chris' hotdog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go with you. We leave Sonja here.    You and me in kayak - we go to Mexico. SONJA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Danish) You're embarrassing.   Idiot. Mads with a burst of re-exhilaration, grabs Chris' hand, shaking it violently. MADS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the meeting you. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm very happy to meet both of you too. Sonja heads back for her hotdog taking her T-shirt off on the move. Chris is about to bust a gut. Sonja returns to her sunbathing. These two are a hoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, something catches Chris' attention upriver. We can just barely make out the SOUNDS of a jet boat motor. His eyes narrow a bit, then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, guys I really appreciate the hospitality but I wanna make camp down- river a ways so I better take off before dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, back in the kayak is paddling down river. Mads and Sonja on the bank, wave a boisterous goodbye. And they just keep waving. And Chris keeps waving until he has drifted out of sight, when around the upriver bend arrive the RIVER PATROL. At river's edge, Mads, thinking quickly, waves for their attention. Pointing the river patrol back upriver, he yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went thattaway!   The crazy man - he went thattaway! And miraculously, the river patrol makes an about face and heads in the opposite direction of Chris. Suddenly Sonja thinks Mads is the most clever man on earth. As she jumps his bones right there on the river's edge -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like in the movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and the kayak are in the back of a pick-up truck heading down river by road. We pass the Hoover Dam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be Christmas in a couple of months. And the last news we'd had was about his car being found. I woke up a couple of days ago, and for the first time, I was surprised to realize that it wasn't only my parents who hadn't heard from Chris. I wondered why he hadn't tried to call in case I might answer. He could've hung up if it wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is re-stocked on some food items which he packs in his bag and shoves into the bow of the kayak. This lower stretch of the river has little in common with the unbridled torrent that explodes through the Grand Canyon. Emasculated by dams and diversion canals, the lower Colorado burbles indolently from reservoir to reservoir, through some of the hottest, starkest, most austere country on the continent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why he didn't send a letter, maybe through a friend. I got mad. But I told myself it was good. It made me remember that there was something more than rebellion, more than anger that was driving him. Chris had always been driven, had always been an adventurer. When he was four years old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris at age four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he once wandered six blocks away from home at three o'clock in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-year old Chris opening a kitchen drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was found in a neighbor's kitchen, up on a chair, digging into their candy drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chris paddles downstream with Mexico in his sights, he is stirred by the saline beauty and the clean slant of light. (Director's Note: ANGLE over Chris ONTO water reflecting the landscape and diamond flashes of sunlight.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever drawer he was opening now must have something sweet in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris floats in SLO-MO through the air, his hair wisping skyward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he pierces feet first, a clear blue surface of the river's water, CAMERA goes UNDERWATER with him and follows him in CU as he surfaces, jubilant in the beauty of the Topock gorge. He shakes the water out of his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris continuing down river through the Imperial National Wildlife Refuge, drifting past saguaros and alkali flats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, on a day hike, the river behind him, he (TELEFOTO LENS played in beautific BACK LIGHT) tracks a herd of wild horses. ANGLE: Chris: The herd moves in an S-pattern. Chris runs beside them and in our LONG LENS PERSPECTIVE, he seems to be among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits outside his tent, beside a campfire scrawling a letter. His "bought-food" bounty in evidence. The words APPEAR ON SCREEN in his handwriting OVER THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUE letter OVER:

dialogues.speaker: THIS TIME.
dialogues.text: Chris moves up the steps of the post office with an enveloped letter in hand. CONTINUE letter OVER:

dialogues.speaker: INT YUMA POST OFFICE
dialogues.text: Chris is in the elegant, 1930's-style post office buying a stamp. CONTINUE letter OVER:

dialogues.speaker: THINK OF YOU AS A FRIEND...
dialogues.text: Chris licks the stamp. Continue letter on screen: GOD BLESS YOU, ALEXANDER. The stamp comes down onto an envelope addressed:

dialogues.speaker: BORDER
dialogues.text: Chris ports his kayak over the dunes, snaking a scar through the sand in his wake. Mexico in his sights. POV: Morelos Dam at the Mexican border.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND, 1990
dialogues.text: Careful not to be seen, Chris shoves off, just upriver from the dam/border. The floodgates are open just enough to allow Chris to lay back in the kayak and drift prone under the gate. He sits back up and paddles through having passed the border, either unnoticed or ignored by patrols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A television set with George Bush plays.   SOUNDS of typewriters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you go to Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd run the whole river into the Sea of Cortez. The stupid dams dried it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is kayaking.   He dead ends in a reeded tributary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you on your own down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers and toes. We see Chris' fingers and toes.   (DOWN ANGLE into interrogation room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the river dried up, I ported the kayak and got a lift to Golfo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Chris jump down off the back of the duck hunter's truck. He slides the kayak off the truck bed onto the street. Chris goes into his pocket, pulls out a sealed sandwich bag of cash. He tries to pay the hunters for their time but they refuse the money. Nonetheless, Chris is insistent and they relent. Chris pulls his backpack from inside the bow and saddles it up on his shoulders. The hunters pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (1000mm lens) LOW ANGLE: SAND AND HEAT WAVES IN FOREGROUND AND BACKGROUND: Chris, paddling his kayak toward us, seemingly in the sand dunes. As we BOOM UP SLIGHTLY, we see that there is a bend in the water's edge and that he is in fact, paddling in the crystalline blue of the Gulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paddled south about 20 miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDER-WATER SHOT: We are directly UNDER the passing kayak as it slices the water's surface above us. We BACKFLIP the CAMERA as it passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when I saw the cave and everything went upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the ocean and sand, wind whipping them. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Chris in a cave where he has made camp; watching, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sandstorm hit and I was pretty much stuck. My kayak blew away, so I left it and walked up the beach, hitched back north, and here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits with the IMMIGRATION OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 days, wow. I guess they're gonna have to watch that spillway a little better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they ought to do is open up the dams and let the rivers flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't disagree with you on that. Okay, Alexander SuperTramp. I think we're gonna let you out of here shortly but you've got two working weeks to get an ID card in the United States. You can't be crossing these borders without identification, are we understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I've eaten enough sand to send me back to the city anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freight train cranks up its great engines and starts its move west. Chris POV: We see a BULL (hobo slang for a railway security guard) making his rounds. As the bull disappears around the caboose, and the trains motion picks up, Chris appears from behind a fuel pump. He makes his move in the shadows to the passing freight cars, not quite sure how to board them. He begins to slowly jog beside the train. There is a vertical steel rod on each passing car. He times the train by putting his hand out and letting the vertical rods slap it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One...Two...Three -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that he accelerates to a run, throws his pack into the moving freight car before him, simultaneously leaping up to grab the rail and throw himself into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But his left foot misses and he's suddenly dangling from the moving train. He grabs hand over hand on the rail. ANGLE: Dangling feet and razor sharp wheels. ANGLE: Chris. He puts everything into pulling himself up, growling the strength into his muscles finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chris rolls forward into the car -- he made it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alexander Supertramp returns to civilization...a hobo. (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a for real hobo. He's very happy about this (despite the near surrender of it.) Chris uses his pack as a pillow, lays back on it and begins to sing Roger Miller's King of the Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TRACK with train by HELICOPTER as we SEGUE from Chris' rendition of King of the Road to Roger Miller's. We let the train get away from us and disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris' train pulls into the yard. Bulls and loaders greet the train. Chris jumps off and breaks for the fence unseen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are crowded with business people on their way to homes and happy hours, buses and parking garages, showers and comforts. Among the throngs, we find Chris walking up Grand Street, backpack on his shoulders. We find he is not such an unusual sight, there are homeless to the left and homeless to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reminder: Condition of Mission is circa 1991) Chris stands at the registration desk talking with a a HEAVY-SET BLACK FEMALE SOCIAL WORKER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell me how to get an ID card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOCIAL WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you lose your identification sir? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. SOCIAL WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No birth certificate? Nothing? Chris shakes his head apologetically. SOCIAL WORKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Alright. Well you're gonna have to work that out with the DMV. You can catch them in the morning. The social worker begins to write an address on a piece of paper. SOCIAL WORKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The closest one is Montebello and we can help you with a bus voucher. She hands the Montebello address to Chris. SOCIAL WORKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, just come to this desk when you need the voucher. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, if I want to apply for a job somewhere, can you help me with that? SOCIAL WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you know how to cook, we might have a space for you in our mobile kitchen. But I'll have to talk to my supervisor about it in the morning. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Thank you. Oh, one last thing. Do you have a bed for me? SOCIAL WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a form) Sure. Just fill this in and I'll get you all set up. Chris begins filling in the form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the next two scenes, there is steady HONKING of CAR HORNS, WAILING of POLICE SIRENS, AMBIENT HOSTILE BANTER, GRINDING ENGINES OF BUSES, puffs of diesel exhaust choke us. 300 HOMELESS occupy nearly as many beds in the dorm. Chris searches the locker wall for his assigned locker. When he comes upon it, he double checks the number with that on the key, opens it, and puts his backpack inside. CU: The lock, as Chris closes and secures his locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walking among the hordes of homeless at 6th and Wall streets. Open fires burn in front of cardboard shacks. There are blacks, whites, Mexicans, even families with children, junkies, winos, hustlers, and hookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE: Chris walking down Broadway. This is clearly just blocks away from where we last saw him, yet the atmosphere is as if of a different world. One of those downtown LA hip yuppie blocks. He comes upon a bar. Through the window Chris sees young men and women roughly his own age - working people, suits, gold-chainers. Metallica blares on the sound system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same CU on locker as before, but this time it's being opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't even see Chris but the camera is his POV as he passes the social worker (same as before) The social worker catches a thrown key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leaving us so soon? I know them DMV lines are long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Director's Note: Traffic and pedestrians move in an accelerated speed while Chris moves nearly in slo- motion.) Chris exits the building into CU.   He looks left, then right, then directly into camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris' train barrels along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris goes into his pack, grabs his canteen and drinks some water. Mid-sip, the train begins to make a surprising stop. Screeching wheels on track. Chris is alarmed. As he moves to peer out the door, even before he has a chance to see what's coming -- WHAM! He's smashed in the head with a baton. A BULL jumps into the car with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay down on your stomach, spread eagle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris turns to reason with the man. And that's all it takes -- six straight blows to the ribs, legs, and arms. We hear it more than we see it. Chris is in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see your face. The bull shines a flashlight into Chris' eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never, ever, ever forget a face. If I see yours again, I won't arrest you. I'll kill you. This is the god-damned railroad. And we will do whatever we have to, to keep you freeloaders from violating our liability. Chris is trying to understand what the man is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If one of you people gets hurt on our train, we are liable. Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despite the violent irony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is pushed off the train, his pack thrown out after him. The bull jumps down beside the track as well and walks down track away from Chris, signalling an "all clear" with his flashlight to some unseen engineer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chris over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stumbles to his feet. The pain of the beating is real. He bleeds from the back of his ear. But he can walk. And he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits on his pack on the roadside, hitchhiking and eating from a can of beans he opened with his pocketknife. The odd car passes but doesn't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris hops out of a Camaro that gave him a ride.   The lighting is anonymous and so is the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks very much. He closes the door and the car drives off. We follow Chris as he goes to the overpass edge. He drops his pack over the side. Chris climbs down the edge of the overpass, grabs his pack, and scurries into the UNDERPASS below. (We suddenly recognize this as his pre-river run campsite) He digs up his buried belongings, returning them to his pack. Last to come out of the ground, Chris' copy of Jack London's Call of the Wild. He pulls off a temp wrapping and dusts it off. Chris lights his candle lantern and begins to read. O.S. VOICES from the PAST:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming, angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about this anymore! Feet stomping off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't walk away from me WOMAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!   I hate you! Sounds of scuffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEVEN-YEAR OLD CARINE sits in the stairwell leading to her parent's room where an argument ensues. Carine's head in her hands, a delicate tear moistens the webs between her small fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIFTEEN-YEAR OLD CHRIS enters from O.S. He leans against the stairwell and looks up the stairs. Our focus remains on Carine. In the B.G. SOFT FOCUS, Walt is pinning Billie down onto the bed. She flails at him but he holds down her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: LOOK WHAT YOUR MOTHER IS MAKING ME DO
dialogues.text: Billie slips his grasp. Walt reaches out with a hit/push of her back. She is thrust out of the bedroom onto the landing above the staircase followed by Walt who positions himself in the doorway like a hostile crucifixion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just cancel Christmas then! Billie returns to him, punching on his chest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are?   God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I'm God! Chris puts his hand out to Carine. She looks up to him. He gives her a smile and a wink. She takes his hand and they exit frame as the argument continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you kids think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not in desperation so much as a demand for their witness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids, get back here! We HEAR a DOOR SLAM OC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Chris and Carine. She sits atop the handlebars of his bicycle beaming as Chris peddles her down the middle of the street. We PULL THEM as they ride. 79aA.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (mockingly) I'll cancel Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: CARINE
dialogues.text: (humored out of her sadness) Who do you think you are? God?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.   I'm God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they both laugh we DISSOLVE BACK to Chris (PRESENT) reading beside his candle lantern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the nine months since Chris' disappearance, my parents went through enormous changes. Guilt was giving way to pain. And pain seemed to bring them closer. My father had humbled dramatically. And what had always been a sort of curt arrogance, the kind of man who actually thought he could cancel Christmas, had given way to the vulnerability of a father's heart. Even their faces had changed. It made me sad that I couldn't share with Chris the new closeness I felt toward our parents. The image of Chris reading begins a SLOW DISSOLVE INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I close my eyes at night sometimes and imagine where Chris might be. Suspicious, ghostly faces briefly appear in the strobing lights that hit the train car from outside. They're toothless and tattooed. Aged and young. Punks and piercings. They're train tramps. We see Chris observing them.   Warmly he speaks but we DO NOT HEAR, "I'm Alex."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there beauty around him?   Was he hurt? Was he alone? We see Chris sharing camp with the train tramps in the outskirts of Las Vegas. DISSOLVE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he having the great adventure that he wanted? We see Chris working as a waiter in a Las Vegas restaurant. DISSOLVE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could he feel the changes here at home? By some kind of supernatural osmosis? Chris once wrote to me from college saying he wanted to talk to me about all the problems he had with mom and dad. We see what may be Chris' POV from a train car snaking through a mountain pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I was the only person in the world who could've possibly understood what he had to say. We see Chris in the Las Vegas desert by a campfire at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE CU: We see Chris walking the streets of Seattle. As we WIDEN OUT, he becomes a dot in the Seattle landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In those silent moments, with my eyes closed trying to picture where Chris might be at that very moment, probably climbing some scary mountain, I want to reach into that picture and bring him back to see what mom and dad, what our family might become. LONG LENS: Chris disappears over the rise into the Seattle marketplace overlooking Puget Sound (per location photography.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But instead when I open my eyes, what I see is my mother, sitting at the dining room table, sifting through photo albums and pictures of Chris. It's all she can do to examine the snapshots. And, though she breaks down from time to time, she studies them with a sort of hungry intensity - like looking at food you can't eat, or into a window at a family around a table that you were once a part of and can be no more. We see Billie driving out of the Annandale supermarket onto the boulevard. She sees a hitchhiker roadside. She cranes her head - is it Chris? It's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She convinces herself it's   Chris; that it's her son, whenever she   passes a stray. And I fear for the    mother in her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Chris hitchhiking in a barren desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instincts that seem to sense the threat of a loss so huge and irreparable that the mind balks at taking its measure - I begin to wonder if I do understand what Chris is saying any longer. But I catch myself in doubt and remember that these are not the parents he grew up with. That in the forced reflection that comes with loss, indeed everything Chris is saying, has to be said. And I trust for him that everything he is doing has to be done. This is our life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is in the passenger seat of a Mac truck cab. Both Chris and the TRUCKER look outward as though to find an address or landmark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where to drop you. Bullhead's kinda haphazard - there's no "center." You sure you don't want to be in Laughlin? It's casinos versus chiropractors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no.   This is good.   Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Chiropractors it is. He pulls over. Chris grabs his pack and exits the truck in front of a laundromat. As the truck pulls away, Chris sees a "Help Wanted" sign for Burger King on the laundromat window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed with a line out the door. LORI, the second assistant manager, hurries back into the kitchen, where we find Chris in paper cap, bunning whoppers at a leisurely pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, you gotta go faster.   We've got a line out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit oblivious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But then just continues on at his leisurely daydreaming pace. Lori is about to say something but by now she knows there's no getting through to him. She looks down to the floor where we see that Chris wears no socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending patience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, I don't mean to be on you about everything. You're doing a great job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to keep you on. And we all want to help you get to Alaska, but you've got to start wearing socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And please.   Hurry.   We're ten deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But the pace remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands at the counter making a deposit with a YOUNG FEMALE TELLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do I have in the account now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like...let me see. Including this latest deposit...One thousand, two hundred and fifty two dollars and...twenty-two cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the interest on twenty-two cents? The young teller giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're TIGHT ON Chris' sock-less feet, pedalling away from the bank on a bicycle. The growing independence of his financial situation felt in the MUSIC OVER: SERIES OF ANGLES as Chris rides out of town, into the desert, from a late afternoon sun into a sunset as he arrives at his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The casino lights of Laughlin, Nevada distantly in B.G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris pedals up a dirt path to find many of his belongings strewn about. And in particular, some food supplies have been torn into. A coyote yips in the distance as Chris finds his old straw hat torn to shreds. Across the desert, scurrying away beyond the tumbleweed, three young coyotes head for the hills. Chris picks up his tattered hat and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are TIGHT on the PUNCHCLOCK as Chris' timecard comes into frame and is punched out. WIDEN OUT to see Chris taking off his paper hat and Burger King overshirt. He walks his timecard over to Lori.   The place is all bu empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lori, I'm punching out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Just put it in the drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean I'm punching out for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy for him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've made our quota, have we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Also, I've got to do some things before I head north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Chris. Well, we've enjoyed knowing you. I won't be able to get that last check to you right away though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.    I'll let you know where to send it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then Chris.    Bye-bye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: City crews string Christmas lights and ornaments along the main drag. We CRANE DOWN to find Chris' bike leaning on a lamppost. A cardboard sign attached to it reads -

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC OVER
dialogues.text: Chris is hitching south on the 95 into the Big Maria Mountains. Beyond him we see a sign for Niland 206 miles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUE MUSIC OVER
dialogues.text: Chris gets a clean shave and a whore's bath. CU: Chris Music FADES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the vista of former barracks foundations Rainey and Jan Burres had told Chris about. Hundreds of people in tents and trailers, a quarter inch to the right of a Rainbow Gathering as hillbillies and renegades mix with the hippies. There are canvas-covered booths set up for swap and trade. Even a few makeshift food stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE that many of the inhabitants have set up CHRISTMAS TREES outside their trailers and tents. Kids play naked in a mud pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158   EXT. THE BOOTH OF JAN & RAINEY, THE SLABS - SAM We see Rainey selling their wares. Beside the booth, their van with its backseat door open. A little dog, Sunni, jumps out the van door, sniffing something out. Jan exits the van after the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunni!    Come here boy. But Sunni has sniffed out Chris' large backpack leaning against the rear of the van. Jan is just beginning to recognize it, when from behind the van appears Chris, looking like a million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overjoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex! As she goes to hug him - ANGLE: Rainey hearing his name, jumps up from his stool to join them. Big embraces all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impromptu campfire celebration with live music from a makeshift stage. Jan, Rainey, and Chris sit on chairs outside the circle of inhabitants, taking in the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell us everything. (Note: This scene should largely be improvised. They all know their characters, their history. Jan and Rainey are doing great. And while Chris is intermittently aware that the eyes of a pretty 16-year old girl are upon him, Chris lays out his travels and his PLAN FOR ALASKA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan remarks, "I guess if you can figure out how to paddle a canoe down to Mexico, hop freight trains, and score beds at inner-city missions, you can figure out Alaska too.") At this point, the PRETTY 16-YEAR OLD GIRL who had had her eyes on Chris, takes the stage with an acoustic guitar, introduces herself as TRACY, then SINGS an innocent love song of her own composition, stealing seductive glances at Chris throughout the performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've made yourself a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's only a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. The girl finishes her song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160   EXT. THE BOOTH OF JAN & RAINEY - DAY Chris and Rainey man the second-hand goods booth while Jan bathes Sunni in a steel bucket by the van. Among the goods, a USED ORGAN. Chris is thrilled to have access to all the second-hand books that are part of Rainey and Jan's inventory. As he skims through Jack London's Odyssey of the North, Rainey notices Tracy sitting on the steps of her vagabond parents' rig across from the booth. She picks silently at her guitar with her bright eyes fixed on Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long can you stay with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm waiting on a check from my last job to come into Salton City the day after Christmas. I've got to start thinking about getting ready for Alaska. When the sun gets a little lower tonight, I'm going to start a calisthenics routine. I think after the check comes in, I'll try to find some mountains I can climb everyday till spring comes. I gotta see how far the money's gonna go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to have to pick up a lot of supplies before spring. So, I might take another job or I might be okay. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, we'll give you a little something for every day you work the booth. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking any money from you, Rainey.   It's been a real great twist meeting you two. You look like you're doing good. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are, and you were a big part of that, coming along when you did. Yep, things are good. (gives a little giggle) Man, I used to think Tantric sex was just a bunch of reading. Speaking of which, don't you think you ought to introduce yourself to Joni Mitchell over there? Chris looks up from his book to the wide open 16-year old smile of Tracy. Rainey laughs aloud. Chris smiles back, and against his better instincts, gives her a little wave over with the paperback. Tracy jumps off her step, putting her guitar inside the rig, and trots like a little wood nymph to Chris. TRACY                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. TRACY                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You selling books? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.   We are. TRACY                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read a lot. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you? TRACY                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.    I heard you play your song last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terrible. Rainey amused by all of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   You sing sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I was going to go watch the kids play in the mud. Do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.   I'll watch the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.   This is Rainey.   And I'm Chris. Whoops, a slip on the name, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Rainey. And this is Alex. ("Don't lie to her.")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Tracy.                                            * Chris realizes his slip but before Rainey can question anything, Chris stands and goes off with Tracy. Rainey and Jan share a conspiratorial smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Salvation Mountain?) (Leonard?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG LENS: We watch Chris and Tracy sit pit-side with a foreground of frolicking naked children splashing about in the mud. We don't hear their conversation. We just watch its gentleness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162   EXT. RAINEY & JAN'S VAN, THE SLABS - NIGHT Tracy helps Rainey cook dinner on the barbecue, meaning to demonstrate to Chris what a wonderful wife she would be. Jan and Chris sipping on beers sit beside each other on folding chairs, out of Rainey and Tracy's earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't much older than Tracy when I got             * pregnant. And I thought my husband and I were going to invent peace on earth and stay together forever. But it didn't work out that way. He left. History. Now ancient history. And that was the end of that. So, I raised Reno by myself - that's my son. Then I met Rainey. And that was really good for a while. But Reno was already a teenager and was becoming a man in his own way. And then, I don't know. He kinda followed in his father's footsteps - out the door and gone. And I really don't know where he is. I haven't heard from him in two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I get to meet him sometime. Jan looks into Chris' eyes and smiles with pure love. She leans over and gently kisses Chris on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your folks know where you are? Chris aims to deflect the question as Tracy enters the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soup's on. Oh, I'm sorry.   Are you guys getting heavy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart. Just hungry. You've been doing a fantastic job over there. (to Chris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tracy grabs Chris' hand and proudly leads him to supper. As they exit frame, we remain for a moment with Jan and her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Chris reading and selling books. 2. Chris and Tracy taking walks with Sunni. 3. Rainey and Jan stealing some afternoon delight in the van. (It's the days of wine and roses) 4. Chris' new daily regimen of calisthenics. 5. Tracy's new daily regimen of watching Chris do calisthenics. His lean body tighter and stronger everyday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 164   EXT. RAINEY & JAN'S VAN, THE SLABS - (CHRISTMAS Rainey stands over Chris as Chris does sit-ups.     Raine gut hanging a little heavy over his belt. OS VOICES exchange Christmas greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really ought to get myself doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should Rainey. Makes that Tantric stuff go even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell would you know? That poor girl over there is about ready to vault onto a fence post. And here you are, the monk of Jack LaLane. They share a laugh. Chris comes to the end of his sit- ups. Wipes his brow with a towel. Rainey squats down next to him. RAINEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Jan filled you in. About Reno and everything. Children can be harsh judges when it comes to their parents. They don't grant clemency easily. I think Reno tended to see things in black and white. I just hope he lives long enough to forgive her. The connection is not lost on Chris. RAINEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But painful as it is, you turned a light on in her and I'm grateful. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? Chris doesn't answer. A kid rides by on a bright new Big Wheel. Must be from the rich side of the commune. RAINEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your folks know where you are? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think they ought to? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should. But I can't. Not yet, anyway. I got a sister though, Carine. She's the most beautiful girl in the world. But, it's all got to stay behind me until I get where I'm going. RAINEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Rainey. Alaska. Rainey won't intrude any further. He just nods. Chris notices Tracy in the door of her parent's rig, stealthily waving him over. Chris gives Rainey the "Uh-oh" look, pulls on his T-shirt, and walks over to the rig. Tracy has disappeared inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?    Merry Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in here. As Chris mounts the steps, he finds Tracy laying on the bed inside, wearing a skimpy white girl's tank top and underpants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deer in headlights)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents went into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they did. They went to call my grandma for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean, no, we can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Chris moves to sit on the edge of her bed.    Tracy sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen. Chris throws her a look of doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What year were you born? As soon as she has to think about it, the jig is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to do something together? Shyly, she shakes her head "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the used Christmas trees of the residents being thrown onto an existing campfire, building into the enormous, celebratory bonfire that lights the scene. As we did with the footsteps in the mud and the kayak slashing the sand, we TRACK VERTICALLY along an extension cord from one of the trailer generators to the stage until we find - Tracy with her guitar and Chris with the second-hand organ from Rainey and Jan's booth on the stage. They enter into a duet of John Prine's Angel from Montgomery for the crowd of the Slabs' fire-lit inhabitants. In the crowd, we find Rainey and Jan clapping and dancing along to Chris and Tracy's song. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan is pulling the van out from their plot.    Rainey is guiding the single-directional vehicle. Chris and Tracy stand beside the car path.    Chris write down Wayne Westerberg's Carthage address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can always get in touch with me by sending mail here. I don't know when I'll get it, but I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am? He hugs her.   And kisses her. (cheek, lips? I don't know.) Jan pulls up in the van. Rainey walks over to Chris and gives him a paternal hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care of yourself, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Rainey. Thanks for everything. Chris gives Rainey's gut a full-hand pinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Year's resolution? Rainey gives him a wink and puts his arm around Tracy as Chris jumps into the car. Then he and Jan hit the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This market/liquor store/post office serves as the cultural nexus for the greater Salton Sea area. As Jan's van pulls up opposite the post office and makes a U-turn to curbside, Chris gets out of the van. Now Jan's eyes really well up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get your pack out of the back and get out of here. I can't take a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris says nothing. He just looks at Jan. They understand each other. Chris closes the door. He fiddles with the broken handle of the back door, gets it open, gets his pack out. On top of his pack, A WRAPPED XMAS GIFT and when he closes the back door, Jan heads straight off back to the Slabs. Chris opens the giftwrap; it's the new hat Jan had promised. Chris is touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TELEPHOTO LENS: A long two-laned road before us rises and falls in a series of saddles and peaks. The narrow shoulders are densely wooded. SLOWLY APPEARING over the near most peak, a TEAM OF EIGHT SHIRTLESS HIGH SCHOOL RUNNERS. Leading the group - 17 YEAR-OLD CHRISTOPHER MCCANDLESS. Lean, softly handsome, and graceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In high school, Chris became captain of the cross-country track team. They called themselves the Road Warriors. REVERSE ANGLE: The group of young runners, led by Chris suddenly veer off the paved road into the adjoining woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF ANGLES: The runners, led by Chris, pace unchartered trails, grassy hillsides, and shallow streams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd take them on what he loved to refer to as "epic" runs. The whole point was to run until they were completely lost and so exhausted that they were on the verge of puking. Then they'd slow down a little, somehow he'd find their bearings, and lead them home again at full speed. This was my brothers idea of fun. We FAVOR Chris as he jogs in place at the exhilarating point of being lost. When he has identified a most likely return route, he quickens his pace, leading the group in the direction of return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris heads out with his last Burger King check in hand, proudly wearing his new hat and in search of mountains to climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year and a half into Chris' disappearance, each day that goes by now feels like two. Dad calls it "suspended animation." I kept telling myself that he had to get lost to prove his independence to himself. But this was no day run for the Road Warriors and after so much time, I could no longer keep out the haunting thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, with pack and new hat walks away from camera toward the interstate and the brittle mountains beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In many ways, my life and even my parents had begun to move in new directions. I'd fallen in love. And mom and dad had even ventured out on a brief vacation. But, when a search of tax records uncovered Chris' contribution to OXFAM, the weight of his disappearance just seemed to lie down on us full length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (JANUARY 1992)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: We see the Oh My God Hot Springs. Steaming pools lined with rocks and shaded by palm trees. A small group of campers and Charlie Manson wannabes in FOREGROUND. We ZOOM past them to the sheer rock faces and landforms of the badlands, several miles beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLO MO: We are looking down a radically steep rock face. A shirtless Chris is in training running towards us under the hot desert sun. We HEAR only breath and footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris rests on the sand under a tarp, hung from a Creosote branch. A plate of beans and rice eaten nearly clean and an empty water jug beside him. Flies buzz and pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris on a morning jog, wearing a shoulder bag and carrying an empty water jug. A quick wave to one of his distant "neighbors" at the spring's camp as he runs by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris continues his jog, cars whisk by and dust kicks into the air. But Chris is undeterred, keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris approaches, slowing his jog to a walk. Chris sets down his water jug and stretches his calves. In the distance we see the peaks of the badlands landforms from where he ran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris shakes off the jog, picks up the jug, and we go with him around the side of the building. There's a water faucet dripping slowly into the desert mud. Chris pops his jug under it and fills it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks the aisles, sipping from his jug, as he comes across bags of rice on the market shelves. A HEAVY SET GIRL passes him in the aisle with her well-mannered dog following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no high-pitched pet voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy. You are a handsome fellow. (over shoulder to the girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. As the girl continues on, the dog wants to stay with Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, boy.    Go on. And the dog obeys him. As he sorts through the various rice selections, brown, white, wild, we notice a MAN peering over the opposite shelf at Chris. This is RON FRANZ, between 70 and 80 years old, six-feet, thick arms, barrel chest, and large ears. He wears old jeans, an immaculate white T-shirt, a decorative tooled leather belt, white socks, and scuffed black loafers. His deeply pitted nose demonstrates a purple filigree of veins which unfold like an finely wrought tattoo. And on either side of it, the wary blue eyes of a soldier. He is the archetypical American man. Chris has caught his sympathetic eye. Chris moves to the counter to pay for rice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In WIDE SHOT, we watch Chris from behind, walking out across the two-lane road. He puts out his thumb to hitch a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a truck comes from BEHIND INTO FRAME heading straight for Chris, the truck makes a relaxed L-turn, pulling up beside Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your camp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out past Oh-My-God Hot Springs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lived in and around here six years now and I've never heard of any place that goes by that name. Ron leans across the bench seat of the truck, opening up the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me how to get there. Chris hops in beside Ron, who extends his hand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron Franz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex.    Where are you from Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Alex from West Virginia. I like a fellow who doesn't raise the pitch of his voice when he talks to animals...shows he doesn't condescend. Chris remembers now the dog in the store and why Ron must've thought to give him a ride. And they head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron truck drives up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we come upon a 4x4 track twisting down a narrow wash -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go left here. Ron turns the truck down the 4x4 track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the truck bump and grind on the mangled dirt road about a mile in. Out the window, Ron's eye has been caught by something. Ron's POV: Oh-My-God Hot Springs - We see a couple of day-glo vans and rusted out Studebakers that hadn't been turned over since Eisenhower was in the White House. Several of those living there mill about buck naked. And at the center of the camp, the steaming pools lined with rocks under the palm trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we keep going. I'm further up. Another half-mile or so, out on the Bajada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and Chris drive up in the truck. Ron shuts off the ignition and gets out of the truck to stretch his legs. Chris follows, puts his full water jug under the tarp at his campsite, hooking it onto a branch. He throws his shoulder bag with the rice in it into his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is somethin' out here. Don't you worry about those dope smokers and nudists down below there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they keep to themselves pretty much and so do I.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Hmmm. You strike me as a bright young man. Am I wrong about that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I think I got my head on my shoulders pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That's what I mean.    How long have you been out here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: And before that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: A lot of places. I've been moving around.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Twenty-three.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Twenty-three years old! Son, don't you think you should be getting an education? And a job? And making something of this life?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Look Mr. Franz. I think careers are a twentieth century invention and I don't want one. You don't need to worry about me. I have a college education. I'm not destitute. I'm living like this by choice.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: In the dirt?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I just don't know.    Where's your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have one anymore. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame. Chris can see some deep sadness in this man. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Franz. I want to show you something. Ron follows Chris to the rockface we'd seen Chris running earlier. They begin to walk up it. It's tough on the old-timer, walking this steep hill. But he's a tough old- timer, at least for the moment... ANGLE: The two men nearly half way to the summit.     It' getting steeper and higher. Ron stops. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is getting a little steep.     And a little high for me kid. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   But look out there. Even from half way out, it's quite a sight isn't it? Their POV: Enormous beautiful vista all the way across the Bajada. CHRIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the top you can see all the way to the Salton Sea too. Ron looks up the precarious rock wall.   He ain't gonna b seeing the Salton Sea today. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see the Salton Sea from up there? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting his way down the hill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to go up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.   I don't do these kind of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris smiles and follows Ron.       As they approach the bottom of the hill -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you and me take a drive? About fifty miles or so up highway, I know a place that's got a view, great food, and requires no climbing. How's that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris thinks about it.     Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. It'll take me a couple of minutes to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron's truck drives through frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ron and Chris driving parallel on the windmilled road (Our frame will only hold the lower fraction of the spinning windmills in the background)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERTICAL POV: We are thousands of feet in the air over the rigid rocky canyon as we ascend toward San Jacinto summit. It's high. Scary HIGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC OVER: As Chris and Ron ride the tram to the peak, we watch Chris watching Ron, his kind, moist old eyes, slowly blinking at the wonder of the nature around him. Other passengers on the tram seem nervous, but Ron is meditative, almost hypnotized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with each roll-through of the tram through the cable towers, the tram car rocks and sways, but Ron's peace goes unbroken. And Chris continues to admire the gentle blinking of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them sit in a quiet, corner   booth of the tramway eatery that sits on the summit   of San Jacinto overlooking the lights of Palm Springs   and the desert clear back to Salton Sea. Chris is on    a roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you, Mr. Franz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-nine years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-nine...see, all due respect, but the real difference between people is the quality of their soul and not on how long they've trudged around like a dip-shit. Ron laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.   No question about that. Ron continues to let Chris vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The government's the same as my parents. They don't respect anybody. Regulation. Regulation. Regulation. WE can't do this. But THEY can do that. I mean, the hypocrisy of the whole...culture.   Makes me crazy. My father was having children                * with two women at the same time, and then              * has the gall to think that he can be of some guidance to me? Make judgments on me? My mother, of course, goes along with all of it. Keeps the secret, which of course, makes my whole life a fiction. Everything I thought was, wasn't. They're such fools! Fucking idiots!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, please don't lump me in amongst your judges. And your tyrants. But I'd prefer to not hear that kind of language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing his slip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I don't usually use that kind of language either. I just get so angry thinking about it. Ron reaches across the table.    Puts his sturdy hand on Chris' shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a lot of passion, young man. Chris smiles at Ron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ron and Chris pull up in the pick-up truck, we see SPORADIC FIREWORKS WHISTLING AND CRACKLING into the air above the hot-springs, and HEAR the distant HOOTING of its inhabitants. Chris hops out and walks around to Ron's side of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awww, that was a great time Mr. Franz. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here. If Charles Manson and his buddies don't kill me on my way out of here, I'd like to cook you up a home cooked meal tomorrow night. If I come out here about, say, four o'clock tomorrow, how would that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be swell. Ron is thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good. I'm no gourmet but I know where the spices are. Good night, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night Mr. Franz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Ron hits the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris hikes up it with his backpack on, one laborious step at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris summiting the rock formation. He looks down over the desert and there before him, The Salton Sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is a single-level, beige structure, sitting between the Salton Sea and a small inlet where he keeps a fishing boat. Underneath a canopy in the backyard, there is a small workshop of some kind. HIGH ANGLE: Chris, looking at his own reflection in the water below Ron's dock. In the reflection, we see his hands full of dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron broils a couple of steaks. Chris enters and moves past Ron carrying his laundry into another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris pours detergent over his long-in-need clothes. Starts the cycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chris enters, Ron is pulling the steaks from the broiler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the kitchen sink, Chris sees a row of approximately ten photographs, each in vertical 4x6 frames, some black and white, some color: all of Japanese boys and girls in formal American and Japanese attire. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find everything you need? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking his gaze from the photographs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I hope I don't wreck your machine. There's a lot of grime in that stuff. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what it's for.   How do these steaks look? Ron pops the steaks on the kitchen table. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sit down. Ron grabs some silverware from a drawer, plops it down on the kitchen table with some paper napkins. RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you drink? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a White Russian? RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer? RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Don't have any alcohol. I had to quit all that. How about a guava juice? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a guava juice, that sounds good. As Ron gets the drinks - RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I had a little spell with the bottle, you could say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron pops the drinks down on the table, then sits with Chris. They lift their glasses toward one another, then - RON/CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent most of my life in the army. On New Year's Eve 1957, I was stationed over in Okinawa. My wife and son were here in the States, just driving down the road when a fellow who'd had too much to drink plowed right into them. Killed them both. Anyway, you might think that the last thing in the world I'd do, is go to the whiskey, but at the time, it felt like the only thing I could do. And I did it hard. But pretty soon, I figured I wasn't doing my wife and son any good, mourning them with a bottle. So, I pulled myself together and quit drinking, cold turkey. And then... Ron, spinning his body around, points to the photographs over the sink. RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening) You see all these kids over here? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was gonna ask you. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's... (pointing at each with his finger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuki, Kenjiro, Yoshiko, Keiko, Masaro, Junichi, Kimpei, Nayoko... For the last picture frame, Ron stands and takes it off the shelf - RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pridefully shows Chris the picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Akira. Just finished medical school. Chris takes the picture and studies Akira's face.   Ron sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I unofficially adopted all of them. It did my heart some good but I guess really it was just writing a few letters and sending some money. Anyway, it was important to me. I get a letter from each of them from time to time. You know. So, since all that, this is pretty much me. (indicating his small reclusive abode)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever travel, Mr. Franz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I can't seem to get too far from my leather. I'll show you after you finish eating. I do a lot of leather engraving. I got a little workshop in the garage. Between that and my pension, I do pretty well. But every time I think I might take a trip somewhere, I get too far behind on orders and such to consider it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having wolfed down the steak)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm finished eating. I'd love to see your workshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would ya? Chris nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Ron picks up the picture of Akira and replaces it on the shelf above the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we begin, Ron is instructing Chris in the skills of leather engraving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, a clear plastic bag of clean laundry beside him, sits alone, cross-legged. He begins to carve into a leather belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Chris in a LOW ANGLE up his mountain run framing from mid-back to just above his head, sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron's truck cuts along the 4x4 track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris reaching the summit.   He bends over to catch his breath, hands on knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about some fishing? Chris turns to the voice. And down at the bottom of the rock wall beside the campsite, is Ron holding up two fishing poles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the Sea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thing's twice as salty as the ocean. Did you know that? Chris has barely the breath to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything alive in it? Ron shrugs his shoulders in a "who cares?" fashion. Chris laughs but nods in the affirmative and gives Ron the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN MUSIC OVER
dialogues.text: 1. Chris and Ron fishing in the Salton Sea. (no catch) 2. At Ron's workshop/garage, Ron guides Chris in his leather belt project. 3. At Chris' campsite, Chris does push-ups while Ron sits on the tailgate of his truck spying on the "Manson family" through binoculars, shaking his head. 4. Chris at his campsite working on the belt by campfire light. We MOVE IN on the belt, he's beginning to form the letter N in the leather. 5. Chris jogging in the morning beside Oh-My-God Hot Springs. 6. Chris and Ron at the leather bench in Ron's workshop/garage. In a EXTREME CLOSE-UP, MUSIC FADES OUT as we PAN across Chris' leather belt and the story being told on it through the engravings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX is inscribed at the belt's left end; then the initials C.J.M. (for Christopher Johnson McCandless) frame a skull and crossbones. Across the strip of cowhide one sees a rendering of two-lane blacktop, a No U turn sign, a thunderstorm producing a flash flood that engulfs a car, a hitchhiker's thumb, an eagle, the Sierra Nevada, salmon cavorting in the Pacific Ocean, the Pacific Coast Highway from Oregon to Washington, the Rocky Mountains, Montana wheat fields, a South Dakota rattlesnake, Westerberg's house in Carthage, the Colorado River rapids, a canoe beached beside a tent, Las Vegas, and at the buckle end, finally, the letter N.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the N stand for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...North.

dialogues.speaker: SKY.
dialogues.text: Ron is sitting on his tailgate, watching Chris, backpack on, climb the stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska? Chris summits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, what the hell you running from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells down from above)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could ask you the same question. Except I already know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, Mr. Franz. You've got to get back out in the world. Get out of that lonely house of yours, that little workshop, and go live on the road. Ron waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. You're going to live a long time, Ron. You should make a radical change in your lifestyle. The core of man's spirit comes with new experiences. And there you are, stubborn old man, sitting on your butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sittin' on my butt, huh? Ron gets up off the tailgate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you sittin' on my butt. And Ron starts making the old man hustle. Shifty shoulders and all, up the stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) "Stubborn old man." Chris is laughing and clapping. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, old man! Come on! RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Ya little pinhead. Chris is jumping up and down, thrilled for Ron's efforts. Now the old man's shuffle has turned into an old man's walk. But he ain't stopping. And bit by bit he shows he's got it in him after all. As Ron is just about to mount the summit, Chris extends a hand. Ron swats it away. RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya little pinhead. Ron drops down onto his back to catch his breath and let his thumping heart slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You alright? Ron, after taking one more deep breath, sits up and Chris sits next to him. He's actually pretty happy with himself. He looks out and sees the distant Salton Sea. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss you when you go. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll miss you too, Ron. But you're wrong if you think the joy of life comes principally from human relationships. God's placed it all around us. It's in everything. In anything we can experience. People just have to change the way they think about those things. You ought to put a little camper on the back of your pick-up and go take a look at some of the great work god's done out here in the American west. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex...You're probably right.   And I'm going to take stock of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris offers a skeptical glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I am. A second skeptical glance.   Which Ron squashes with genuine sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Chris buys it this time and feels he's accomplished something with Ron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll tell you something. The bits and pieces I've put together, you know, what you've told me about your family. Your mother and dad. And I know you got your problems with the church too, but there's some kind of bigger thing that we can all appreciate. And it sounds like you don't mind calling it God. But when you forgive, you love. And when you love...God's light shines on you. Miraculously, it is just at that moment that the cloud clears from the sun and the light shines in Ron's eyes. Chris points at Ron's face at the light shining on him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you about that language. The two men, their eyes welling up, fall back laughing. EXTREME WIDE SHOT FROM BELOW: The two men on the summit with the echoing of laughter and Ron's screams -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you so! I told you so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris pulls his laundry out of the dryer. He's got his pack sitting in the doorway to the kitchen. He folds his things and tucks them into his pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron appears in the doorway dressed for travel. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing up?     It's three-thirty in the morning. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard you get up off the couch half an hour ago, and had a funny feeling you might not be here for our breakfast. Chris says nothing. RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to drive you a hundred miles to somewhere where you can pick up a train, a plane, or hitch a ride without getting stuck on this desert. I'd take you all the way to Alaska if I didn't have to get to an eight o'clock mass. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron, you don't have to do that. RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do it.     Get you started on this thing of yours. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my Great - RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know. On your "Great Alaskan Adventure." From just out of Chris' eye-line, Ron leans out of frame, picking up a zippered duffel bag. He opens it, displaying the contents to Chris. RON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a machete, an arctic parka, collapsible fishing pole, and a few odds and ends I threw in there for you. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron... RON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just take it. Chris does, nodding his thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait for you in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the two men (on this nondescript locale) driving along the highway east from dawn through sunrise. They ride in silence through Coachchella Desert Center and Blythe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck exits at a North/South junction 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ron begins to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Both of them are uncomfortable. Chris goes for the door handle. Ron's gnarled hand reaches out to take Chris' elbow. After a long beat, Ron speaks without looking at Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had an idea. You know my mother was an only child. So was my father. And I was their only child. Now, with my own boy gone, I'm the end of the line. When I'm gone, my family will be finished. What do you say, you let me adopt you. I could be, say, your grandfather. This takes Chris by surprise.   He knew it would be hard but not this hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about we talk about this when I get back from Alaska, Ron. Would that be alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Ron nods.   Releases Chris' elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Ron. We'll talk about it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to mask. The blinking, moist eyes again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.   We can do that, yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ron. Ron nods. Chris gets out of the truck. Ron watches as Chris saddles up his bag including the duffel that Ron gave him. Chris crosses the exit junction to where he can pick up a ride north on the far side of the road. We ZOOM SLOWLY through the windshield into Ron's face as he watches Chris hitching away. We HEAR the first bars of Neil Young's My My, Hey Hey. This will carry throughout the following MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. We ZOOM into Walt McCandless' face as he looks through the Questar telescope that Chris had given him. ANGLE: The stars through the telescope. The same stars his son walks under...somewhere. We PAN ACROSS SPACE. (Note: This montage will intercut Chris' traveling POV with objective shots. However, we never SEE Chris.) 2. We PULL BACK from the starry night sky to see it framed from within a moving train. 3. Carine in her shower, water cascades over her face. 4. Billie in her kitchen, making dinner. 5. Through the windshield of a semi-truck, the sun rises on Glacier National Park. 6. A HANDHELD ZOOM-OUT from Canadian border crossing, CAMERA TURNS to the woods beyond and MOVES INTO THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7. SERIES OF TRAVELING SHOTS: (Through Skookumchuk and Radium Junction, Lake Louise to Prince George and Dawson Creek) STATIC NATURE SHOTS: HELICOPTER SHOTS 8. On the bed in their van, Jan sits on Rainey's bare feet while he does sit-ups. 9. Ron holding a garage sale, while hooking a trailer to his truck. 10. Wayne being released from jail. 11. Mads and Sonja, side by side, one-armed bandit-ing in a Vegas casino. 12. Tracy at a high school dance, slow-dancing with her young date. 13. Looking through the windshield of another semi. A bear lopes across the two-lane road before us. We PAN and ZOOM with it into the tundra beside the road. HANDHELD, WALKING, we pass Mile 0 of the Alaska highway: The sign: Fairbanks 1523 miles. 14. A waterfall. 15. Intercut hand and thumb hitching - a sense that rides are few and far between. 16. A misting mountain peak. 17. Beavers in streams. 18. Melting blue ice-walls. 19. A lynx skittering across a snowy mound. 20. Walt and his telescope. 21. The hitchhiker's VIEW on a two-lane road, walking past a highway sign for the Yukon Territory. (Through Johnson's Crossing, Whitehorse, and Beaver Creek.) 22. From a passenger car window, a series of road signs reading: Closed for winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a month short of the second anniversary of Chris' disappearance, I had gotten engaged to my boyfriend Jerry Ray and was moving in with him... Carine, packing her belongings into boxes, stumbles upon the Sharon Olds book Chris had given her on his graduation day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...when I stumbled upon the book Chris had given me on his graduation day. For some reason, it was the last line of the poem he read that really stuck out. FLASH BACK: (From page 2-3)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is holding a book from which he reads aloud the LAST LINE OF THE POEM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I will tell about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked Chris who had written the poem. What we SEE of Carine plays with the VOICE OVER TRACK and SILENT with the production track; in essence lip synching herself. Chris' dialogue comes directly from the flashback image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wrote that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it could've been either one of us. Couldn't it? We see pictures of Chris on the night-stand of Walt and Billie's bedroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would he tell about now?   What did his voice sound like now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
