dialogues.text: I realized that the words to my thoughts were of less and less meaning. Chris was writing his story and it had to be Chris who would tell it. The pictures in the scene BLUR as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a far away, tunnel-like sound)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie sitting bolt upright in the middle of the night, tears rolling down her cheeks. Walt awakens beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't dreaming! I didn't imagine it! I heard his voice, Walt. I heard Chris. Walt takes her in his arms, trying to squeeze life into both of them.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBANKS ALASKA, SERIES OF STATIC IMAGES
dialogues.text: Berms of cleared snow line the streets 1. A GAS STATION (Gold Hill Gas and Liquor) We see Chris' writing appear on screen:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: 9. A SIGN AGAINST A RADIO TOWER "RADIO FAIRBANKS"(Perhaps we hear a weather report)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to the area of Scene #1. MUSIC OVER: Of religious scope.    Perhaps choral. HELICOPTER SHOT: We travel a long ways across snowy peaks and valleys (clearly far from anywhere) passing between two escarpments of outer range bordering bottomlands five miles wide until we barely see a tiny form within it trudging through the snow. We overfly it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, crunching through two to three feet (not more) of snow, in arctic parka, big boots, his warm hat, rifle slung over his shoulder, and pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves TOWARD CAMERA. We PAN AROUND with him as he walks past, where beyond Chris on the snow plain, rises a tree line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its banks lined with a jagged shelf of frozen overflow. At its center, a channel of gently flowing water, opaque with glacial till. Beyond the far ice shelf, Chris appears from the riverside treeline. He eases across the ice, then wades through the latte-colored channel and on to the other side. REVERSE ANGLE: Chris moving toward the opposite tree line, he turns back to the gentle river behind. Chris' POV scanning the terrain. From the river to a distant mountain peak and then to a second mountain peak, triangulating his location. He makes a drawing on a pad of paper and piles some medium- sized rocks to mark the spot before moving on into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total silence across the beatific white vista of snow, mountain, and colorless trees UNTIL a DISTANT ECHOING GUNSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris has skinned and is cooking a squirrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris packs the last of his camp and begins his march upriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chris walks upon a clearing in the tree line, he catches his first glimpse of Denali's (Mt. McKinley's) high-blinding white bulwarks. Chris stands in awe. We remain in his WIDE-SHOT POV as it -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: But now Chris' tent sits in its foreground with the moonlit Denali still visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ANGLED SKYWARD into the broken rays of grey light. We TILT DOWN to find (and TRACK through the trees with) Chris moving along the river, when he sees something just OFF CAMERA. Chris' POV: Through the trees and fireweed, he sees something metallic and rusty. Chris moves up through the underbrush and the snow into the narrow tree line and on into the clearing, where before him: A DERELICT SCHOOL BUS. It is a vintage International Harvester from the 1940's. Chris approaches the bus, lifts the hood a little bit seeing that the engine is gone. As he moves around the vehicle, we see several windows are cracked or missing altogether. The green and white paint is badly oxidized. Weathered lettering: Fairbanks City Transit System Bus 142.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broken whiskey bottles litter the floor. Chris may well have found his new home. The bus is outfitted with a bunk and a barrel stove. Previous visitors had left it stocked with matches, bug dope, and other essentials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Chris back out of the bus, surveying the area of the clearing. He loves what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATORY MUSIC OVER
dialogues.text: He runs up a berm to look down into the river. He runs from corner to corner of this "Magic Bus" area like a new bride surveying her honeymoon suite with glee. He climbs a tree, swings from its branch, doing a flip in the air, landing on his feet, but then slipping on the snow and onto his butt and then onto his back. He grabs a handful of snow, shoves it in his mouth, melts it into water, and swallows it. CRANE SHOT:   We PULL UP from Chris to high above the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He re-enters the bus and pulls his pen from his pocket, scribbling on the wall of the bus:

dialogues.speaker: VOYAGER WHOSE HOME IS...
dialogues.text: ANGLE: Chris:   He continues to write as he SPEAKS the words aloud:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the road. Escaped from Atlanta. Thou shalt not return `cause the "west is the best." And now after two rambling years, comes the final and greatest adventure. Chris is cleaning up the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The climactic battle to kill the false being within and victoriously conclude the spiritual revolution. Chris shoveling snow away from the bus entrance with a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten days and nights of freight trains and hitchhiking, bringing him to the great white north. Back to Chris, REAL TIME as he continues to write as he speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No longer to be poisoned by civilization, he flees, and walks alone upon the land to become lost in the wild. Chris signs his doctrine -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris posts a found piece of paper on the inner wall of the bus alongside his doctrine. CU: Chris' hand, he writes and circles the number: 1 - MAGIC BUS DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris comes out, rifle in hand. We TRACK with him as he moves into the woods on the hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris searching for game. He moves through the woods along the river and at the base of a nearby mountain. Finding animals for food seems more difficult than expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stumbles upon a caribou as it steps out from the woods. He lines up his rifle on the animal, about to pull the trigger, when its calf appears beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers his rifle, unwilling to take a shot that would separate mother and child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spruce grouse is spied on a foreground branch.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: The branch splinters and the bird makes haste. ANGLE: Chris, rifle in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, cooking rice. We see his single bag of rice.     I amount tells us the hunting had better improve soon. We explore a PASSAGE OF TIME throughout which CHRIS GETS INCREASINGLY THIN AND PALE: hunting, sleeping, cooking, rice dwindling, line-ups of scrawny shot birds. He adds holes to his belt leather to accommodate his shrinking waistline.

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: Chris bags a squirrel on a snowy plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris eats his measly catch but looks to his bag of rice with concern, perhaps only a day or so left of his rations. We come to the diary/log posted on the wall. We see that he has been there for a week's worth of entries as the squirrel is mentioned on day seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is awakened by a new May sun, streaming light through the windows of the bus. POV: the sun, circling high in the heavens.    Snowmelt dripping quickly across the windowpane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris dances atop the bus, naked in the new spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris shaves. (Note: We are in a time of year in this part of the world where the sun dips behind the horizon only four hours a day)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT: SERIES OF ANGLES throughout which Chris remains thin but his pallor improves: 1. The diary/log representing a small improvement on the hunting front. 2. Undergrowth exposing itself through snowmelt. 3. Establish a small waterfall near the bus. Landing on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow has now all but vanished except on north-facing slopes and shadowy ravines, exposing a range carpeted in an amalgam of muskeg, alder thickets, and veins of scrawny spruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris traipses along the seasons rose hips and lingonberries, which he gathers in great quantity and snacks on as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris shoots a porcupine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diary/log: DAY 30 - PORCUPINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands triumphant at the peak of a 3000 foot butte overlooking the bus. CIRCLE CAMERA around him 360 degrees recording the broad vista. ANGLE: CU - He's beaming with satisfaction. We begin a SLOW ZOOM OUT and then accelerate the ZOOM encompassing the entire grandeur of the mountain with Chris at its peak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diary/log: DAY 31 - CLIMBED MOUNTAIN

dialogues.speaker: COLLAGE TIME IN A SERIES OF DISSOLVES
dialogues.text: 1. The diary/log: MAP AREA. Chris surveying and taking notes of area. 2. The diary/log: IMPROVISE A BATHTUB AND SMUDGE POT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris building a bathtub out in the front. 3. The diary/log: COLLECT SKINS AND FEATHERS TO SEW INTO CLOTHING. Chris hunting and skinning. 4. The diary/log: CONSTRUCT BRIDGE ACROSS NEARBY NARROW CREEK. Chris knee-deep in slow-moving water constructing a make- shift bridge across narrow creek. 5. The diary/log: BLAZE NETWORK OF HUNTING TRAILS. Chris making a trail with his machete when - A MOOSE appears from a nearby thicket. Chris drops the machete and pulls his rifle from his shoulder. The moose looks ready to charge Chris. There's no choice. Chris aims carefully and fires six straight shots into the moose's head, dropping it. Chris can hardly believe his own success. He puts the rifle back on his shoulder, just staring at the dead moose. He begins back-pedalling away from it. Bit by bit, his steps turn into a jog and then he turns and runs back toward the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Director's Note: Handheld) Chris scrambles through his pack and finds the piece of paper where he had written notes of how to cure beef by smoking it, taught to him by Kevin, Wayne's hunter friend back in South Dakota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the kill, the slow process of butchering begins. (This ain't going to be pretty.)

dialogues.speaker: ENTRIES
dialogues.text: 1. The diary/log: BUTCHERING EXTREMELY DIFFICULT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2. The diary/log: FLY AND MOSQUITO HORDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3. The diary/log: REMOVE INTESTINES, LIVER, KIDNEY, ONE LUNG, STEAKS. 4. The diary/log: GOT HIND QUARTERS AND LEGS TO STREAM. 5. The diary/log: REMOVE HEART. 6. The diary/log: DIGS SMOKER HOLE INTO EXISTING CAVE. 7. The diary/log: HAUL NEAR CAVE. 8. The diary/log: TRY TO PROTECT WITH SMOKER. 9. The diary/log: CAN ONLY WORK NIGHTS.   KEEP SMOKERS GOING. 10. The diary/log: MAGGOTS ALREADY. SMOKING APPEARS

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE. GREAT TRAGEDY.
dialogues.text: 11. The diary/log: ABANDON CARCASS TO WOLVES. We see Chris hidden behind a rise, watching a WOLF PACK tug at the rancid meat from the carcass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In and out of the bus. Day and night, portraying Chris mourning his killing of the moose. He even plants a cross by its skeletal remains.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Sunrise and nature awakens. Bird songs and flower blooms. A waterfall cascades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris reading Tolstoy's Family Happiness. His POV: The page: what Chris reads: I have lived through much and now I think I have found what is needed for happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, secluded life in the country with the possibility of being useful to people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits amongst the pink bunches of fireweed choking the vehicles wheel wells, growing higher than the axles, his back leaning against the bus, finishing the reading of Family Happiness. ANGLE: Chris, reading with great interest.   His POV: The page: what Chris reads: And then, on top of all that, you for a mate, and children, perhaps - what more can the heart of a man desire? ANGLE: Chris: He looks up from his book. A gentle breeze tickles morning flowers. The sunlight dances in a coppice of aspen and leaves of trees above. The sound of buzzing flies mutes. He is taking one last look at his paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris showers (PHOTO-SONIC) MUSIC, LYNYRD SKYNYRD'S Simple Man (lyrics in cursive) begins to play OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My momma told me / when I was young Chris packs his gear. Come sit beside me / my only son A last look about the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen closely / what I say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full pack and rifle mounted in WIDE SHOT beside the Sushana River. If you do this it will help you / some sunny day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take your time / don't live too fast We pass the familiar landmark of the Mt. McKinley clearing where Chris had camped. Troubles w ill come / and they will pass Chris walking and camping his way back to the Teklanika River and the road home. Find a woman / you'll find love and don't forget son / there's someone up above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the trees beside the river, we find Chris. The river is not yet in sight but Chris starts to HEAR it: A building rumble. As Chris exits the treeline, there she is: The Teklanika at full flood. Seventy-five foot wide banks, replacing the narrow ice canal of four months earlier. Snowmelt from glaciers high in the Alaska range, its opaque glacial sediment the color of wet concrete. And what had been a distant rumble in the woods, now had the volume and power of a freight train, a seventy-five foot wide one. Chris grabs a hold of a riverside branch and takes one slow, careful step into the river. Without mercy, WHAM! the river kicks his feet out from under him! The branch he holds SNAPS! By some miracle, his hands move like lightening and he grabs a lower, sturdier branch below, saving himself from a certain death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the broken branch catapulted down river and into a rocky shoot below. He pulls himself back onto the bank, drops his pack at riverside, and eases to a sitting position beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pouring rain outside.   The rain pelts the top of th bus. Chris' pack is thrown onto the bunk. His hand appears at the diary/log on the wall. He writes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CU: Beaded and shimmering from the past night's rain, a bright red berry moves in the breeze like a tiny vibrating bell. RACK FOCUS to Chris' eyes spying it. He plucks it from its stem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris adds another hole to tighten his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris looking very thin. Too thin. He is noshing on a bag of collected berries while reading from Boris Pasternak's Doctor Zhivago. ANGLE: The book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she stopped and, closing her eyes, took a deep breath of the flower-scented air of the broad expanse around her. It was dearer to her than her kin, better than a lover, wiser than a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: Chris pulls more berries from the bag and chews on them as he reads. ANGLE: The book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, she re-discovered the purpose of her life. She was here in earth to grasp the meaning of its wild enchantment and call each thing by its right name. ANGLE: Chris

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (echoing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By its right name. By its right name. He puts down the book and brings one of the ripe berries in front of his face (as close as shot of when he picked it.) Chris then grabs Tanaina Plantlore, the flora and fauna book he had gotten from the library in Fairbanks. And it takes him out of the bus like a divining rod. His nose in the book, he follows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plant to plant.   Bush to bush. SPEAKING ALOUD the names of everything he sees as he identifies them with the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful blueberries - Vaccinium uliginosum. Eskimo potato - Hedysarum alpinum...etc. We follow Chris over a number of days as he eats from these identified species of plant, each being logged, one by one by name on the bus diary/log.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Tanaina Plantlore by his side, Chris digs into the soft earth on the berm of the river bank and digs up a wild potato root.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris pulls the seeds from the root, noshing on them as he reads from Doctor Zhivago. We drift from him reading to the diary/log on the wall. The day representing: July 24th The diary/log: WILD POTATO ROOT We drift back to Chris. Fatigue shows in his eyes as he puts the book down and lays down to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT of the bus. It's a beautiful July morning. Birds chirp in the trees. A soft breeze sweeping down from the mountains massages the valley below. We SLOWLY ZOOM into the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open bag of seeds beside Chris' sleeping body. We drift over to Chris' face, his lips de-hydrated, and skin parched. He breathes heavily. He awakens. He tries to sit up. It's a terrible struggle. Barely makes it to his feet. Chris stumbles to the door of the bus, looking up at the hot sun. He has to sit back down on the small bus steps. From his position on the step, he leans back into the bus and is able to grab his water jug. He pours it into his mouth but nothing seems to satiate or hydrate him. He drinks it all. It spills over his face and chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We observe Chris for a moment as the wheels turn inside his haunted eyes. And a curiosity seems to overtake him. He crawls back to his copy of Tanaina Plantlore, flipping the pages one by one until he arrives at the photograph identifying the wild potato root and the word "edible" beside it. He reads the page to its conclusion and as almost an afterthought, turns the page to see if there might be more. The word -

dialogues.speaker: POISON
dialogues.text: jumps off the page at him. The book describes the tiny green seeds of the potato root and warns that those with: lateral veins, such as those invisible on the leaflets of wild sweet peas are poisonous. The words - ...leading to partial motor paralysis... ...inhibition of digestion... ...nausea, starvation...

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: CRASH ZOOM into Chris' face, realizing his desperate plight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris kneels, holding one of the potato seeds to the sunlight and there we see them - the lateral veins that indicate poisonous seeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: The diary/log: EXTREMELY WEAK. FAULT OF POTATO SEED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, barely able to walk, moves, at the pace of an elderly man, with his rifle, through the underbrush.    H needs food now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoots a squirrel. But as he moves toward what he thinks is his kill, the squirrel makes off with a bleeding tail. Chris fires several desperate shots at the squirrel but misses with each one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, having a fitful sleep.   Short breaths and mutterings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big moon shines above and we find on a tree branch, the squirrel Chris had clipped in the tail earlier in the day. On the last legs of bleeding to death, it falls from the tree. The moon becomes the sun and we pass a couple of days through visions of the nature about in varying light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris labors up the riverbank with his water jug full. He is shirtless and absolutely emaciated. Frightening. He pauses at the river's edge to take air into his lungs. It's all he can do just to breath. WIDE ANGLE TABLEAU (CONTINUOUS): Chris standing at the river's edge catching his breath framed against the background of the 3000 foot butte that he'd so recently climbed with ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, maintaining this tableau, something moves from near CAMERA RIGHT into frame. Bit by bit we'll realize it's a LARGE BEAR ENTERING FRAME and moving away from camera toward Chris. It lumbers to within feet of him. CU OVER BEAR onto Chris: Chris, passive to the bear's presence. ANGLE: The bear, just as passive towards Chris, as though he didn't represent enough of anything to eat. BACK TO TABLEAU as the bear, passing Chris, disappears over the rise toward the river. Chris, a motionless and slight silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris lays on the floor. CU Chris: Orange light twinkles in his eyes. Chris' POV: through the bus window, we see the orange glow of smoke rising into the air. CU: Chris writes in his diary log.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set small signal fire today - watched it die tonight. Back to POV as the ambient orange light fades into the blackness of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diary/log: DAY 100 - MADE IT. BUT IN WEAKEST

dialogues.speaker: A SUBTLE DRUM, (HEART)
dialogues.text: Chris plops himself down into the middle of the bus. He shakes his head as if trying to say something, and then considers his rifle and abundant ammunition. But taking his own life to avoid the agony of starvation is not an option for him. "No, no, no, don't do this to me." The frustration builds enough adrenaline in him to scream out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does, but with a low, gurgled animal sound. He shakes it off and looks to his copy of Doctor Zhivago for distraction. Thumbing through the pages he focuses his eyes on the page - ANGLE: The page: what he reads: CHRIS (V.0)(O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that an unshared happiness is not happiness... Chris steals his pencil from within the pages of the book, scribbling across the page: CHRIS (V.O.)(O.C.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: HAPPINESS ONLY REAL WHEN SHARED.
dialogues.text: He flips backwards a couple of pages to where he had written the quote: CHRIS (V.O.)(O.C.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CALL EVERYTHING BY ITS RIGHT NAME.
dialogues.text: He tears the back cover off the book and scratching the pencil across its blank side, writing these words quickly, as if in panic:

dialogues.speaker: MAY GOD BLESS ALL
dialogues.text: And now, these words arrive slowly as we HEAR Chris repeating: CHRIS (O.C.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a weak voice) Call everything by its right name. The drumbeat increases as he signs the note: CHRISTOPHER JOHNSON MCCANDLESS. We move from the page back up to Chris. We see that he has put on his eyeglasses to strengthen the vision of his weakening sight. He removes them, folds them, and lays them by his side. His body begins to tremble. His eyes dance wildly. The drumming intensifies. Chris takes one last look out the window. The sun is covered by a well-defined and puffy cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His arm nearing spasm reaches up to the bunk, grasping at the blue sleeping bag made by his mother. With great suffering and shattering trembles, he forces his body to defy its agony and pushes it into the sleeping bag. SKYWARD, the cloud obscuring the sun. Drumbeats ESCALATE - BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! We TIGHTEN on Chris' anguished face. (Director's note: These CU's on Chris' face, combine both static and hand-held CUs, upside down and right-side up moving, zooms, and push-ins. Straight, side, and dutch angles. Perhaps some intermittent distortion.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We INTERCUT between Chris and the sky in a dance transitioning to the next world. It is hopeful, anguished, sad, and elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, approaching the Annandale house.    His backpack o and body healthy. Billie parts the curtains, ecstatic to see Chris approach, alive and healthy. We SEE but do not hear her call to Walt. A smiling Chris steps up the curb, approaching home. Walt and Billie - we PUSH INTO them as they gleefully run out the front door to their returning son. PUSH INTO Chris - he dispatches his backpack to the ground and runs toward his parents' embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you saw me running into your arms... Chris, Walt, and Billie on the cusp of a jubilant and loving embrace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you see then... The DRUMMING resumes with a BLAST OF BASS and before an embrace is possible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what I see now?

dialogues.speaker: TOTAL SILENCE
dialogues.text: Chris looking at the sky, a cathartic tear falls from his left eye. Another from his right as the obscuring cloud clears the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris: The LAST, AIRY EXPULSION OF HIS BREATH. His open face as the clearing light of the sun shines in his eyes. It is a face of peace, love, a face of true, deep serenity. The eyes joyously open and the corners of his mouth ease into the subtle smile of euphoric wisdom. That's the way he settles to stillness, looking directly into our camera. And he died alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made it.   He lived.   He loved. Cat Stevens' Miles from Nowhere plays OVER: As we PULL AWAY from Chris' face through the bus window and up into the sky - We drift further and further away, above the stunted trees and the shimmering roof of the bus like a tiny white gleam in a wild green sea grows smaller and smaller. REPRISE IMAGE of truck driver taking picture of Chris in scene #1. Then it's him: The smiling STILL IMAGE we saw taken in the first scene from behind, but now we are seeing it from the front and it is the image of the real Christopher McCandless on the edge of the Stampede Trail. As it takes over the screen, we ZOOM SLOWLY into his smiling face. And then, these words appear superimposed over it: Dedicated to the memory of Christopher Johnson McCandless February 12, 1968 - August 18th, 1992 As those words dissolve, these words appear: On September 19, 1992, Carine McCandless flew with her brother's ashes from Alaska home to the eastern seaboard. She carried them with her on the plane...in her backpack.
